The radical is technically <radical>blood</radical>, but you know that radical is just a drop (of blood) on a plate. So, you ask yourself... Is that really blood on the plate? Could it be? You decide to take a gamble and lick it off. When you taste it, it's definitely not blood. No, it's <reading>ketsup</reading> (<ja>けつ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Feel the relief that you didn't just lick up someone's blood. Taste the ketsup taste, too. It's pretty good. Not quite ketchup, but not quite catsup. Yum!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>lid</radical> covering all the <radical>mouth</radical>s that are too <radical>small</radical> to feed themselves, forming the <kanji>capital</kanji>. All of the small mouths come together and create a place where everyone can support each other.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the capital of your country. How many mouths have come together to support each other there? A thousand? A million? More?!
data.reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading <ja>きょう</ja> we use the Japanese city, Kyoto, which is spelled <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. It was once the capital of Japan! It was soooo full of mouths that came together that it was the capital for a long, long time.
data.reading_hint: When you think of the capital, think of <ja>きょうと</ja>!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>king</radical> extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his <kanji>country</kanji>, give or take a few <radical>drop</radical>s.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.
data.reading_mnemonic: Turns out the king of this <kanji>country</kanji> loves drinking <reading>Coke</reading> (<ja>こく</ja>). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast.
data.reading_hint: Would you drink that much soda for breakfast? Now this king says he wants to pass a law requiring everyone in the country to drink nothing but Coke! That's crazy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> is wearing a <radical>lid</radical> and is standing outside in <radical>winter</radical>. Plus it's raining and he's covered in <radical>drop</radical>s of water. On top of all this, it's <kanji>night</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: If it helps, you can come up with a reason why he's outside in the winter at night. Also, why is he wearing a lid on his head? Probably because he's protecting his people from something that comes at night.
data.reading_mnemonic: Question is, what is he protecting them from during the <kanji>night</kanji>? Turns out, it's the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (<ja>や</ja>) baseball team. They're out for blood, and only the leader can protect us.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the Yankees stomping towards the leader, baseball bats in hand, blood on their faces. They're here to eat, and nobody will stop them. Feel the fear of their approach. Will you survive another night with them on the prowl?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Who's that <radical>woman</radical> pretending to be a <radical>jet</radical>? That's my <kanji>younger sister</kanji>. *Sigh*
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>younger sister</kanji> is giving some <reading>mi</reading>ce (<ja>まい</ja>) a ride on her back like a jet.
data.reading_hint: Ew, gross. Your younger sister is such a weirdo! Why does she have mice on her back while pretending to be a jet?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>woman</radical> in this <radical>city</radical> is your <kanji>older sister</kanji>. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.
data.meaning_hint: You want to go to the city someday, but you're not old enough yet, like your older sister is.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>older sister</kanji> may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet.
data.reading_hint: Picture your older sister and her sheep walking through the city. Everyone turns to stare at them, because they're the only ones of their kind.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A long time ago, someone put up a <radical>canopy</radical> over their <radical>fortune</radical> telling booth and created the first <kanji>shop</kanji>. This <kanji>store</kanji> was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!
data.meaning_hint: Picture the very first store in history. A fortune teller decided enough was enough, they should be in some kind of structure where it's safe, official looking, and more permanent.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>shop</kanji> quickly turned into <reading>ten</reading> (<ja>てん</ja>) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more.
data.reading_hint: Picture ten shops, all made up of someone selling something under a canopy. The first one is the fortune teller, but the nine others are whatever you want them to be!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> AND the <radical>moon</radical> are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly <kanji>bright</kanji> outside.
data.meaning_hint: Look up at both of them, hanging out in the sky together. Make them super bright, so bright you have to shield your eyes.
data.reading_mnemonic: When do things start to get <kanji>bright</kanji> outside? I'd say when things start getting sunny, and that is the month of <reading>May</reading> (<ja>めい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: If your months don't match up with this too well (if you're down in the southern hemisphere, for example) then you'll have to imagine all this up in the Northern Hemisphere. Sorry about that, South Hemisphere folks.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Behind that <radical>tree</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> is rising in the <kanji>east</kanji>. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the sun behind the tree, don't picture the sun alone, you'll burn your eyes. It's slowing coming up behind it. Now think: where does the sun rise? In the east!
data.reading_mnemonic: You walk <kanji>east</kanji> for a few hours until you finally come to a city. It's <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Oh! <ja>とうきょう</ja> is in the east. I get it now!
data.reading_hint: When you think about East Japan think about <ja>とうきょう</ja>. And if you're bad at geography, just look at a map for a while. Or, stand outside in the morning, watch the sun rise behind the trees, and point that way. That's east, it's where <ja>とうきょう</ja> is!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stop</radical> at a <radical>small</radical> <radical>slide</radical>. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were <kanji>walk</kanji>ing.
data.meaning_hint: Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say "keep walking, friend."
data.reading_mnemonic: So, you're <kanji>walk</kanji>ing around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a <reading>hoe</reading> (<ja>ほ</ja>) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you.
data.reading_hint: Of course, imagine the pain of your face. Did your nose break? After bringing yourself together, look down at what hit you. It's a hoe! How did you manage to step on just the right spot to flip it up on you like that? Examine the hoe. Pay close attention to it. Whose hoe is this? etc.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a close-up of a <radical>leaf</radical> in a <radical>rice paddy</radical> inside of a <radical>box</radical>. Wait, it's not a box, this whole thing is just a <kanji>drawing</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Look closely at this box-shaped drawing. See each little stroke, smell the paper and the lead.
data.reading_mnemonic: The drawing seems to have something else in the rice paddy, behind the leaf. You realize the drawing is actually of a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (<ja>が</ja>) and a <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>). You see the cock sitting on top of the gargoyle, crowing into the sky.
data.reading_hint: Picture the entire drawing. There's a cock sitting on a gargoyle, watching over this rice paddy. It's actually quite beautiful and idyllic.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You accidentally stab your <radical>cross</radical> into the <radical>eye</radical> of a <radical>lion</radical>. This is a terrible thing you did and you need to <kanji>fix</kanji> it right now. I'll be <kanji>direct</kanji> with you, this is something you have to fix on your own.
data.meaning_hint: How will you fix this mistake though? Maybe if you build a time machine you can go back and stop yourself from throwing your cross around so carelessly. Whatever you do, focus on how important it is to fix the mistake, more than anything.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you try to <kanji>fix</kanji> the lion's eye, it starts to <reading>choke</reading> (<ja>ちょく</ja>) and make what can only be described as a <reading>jiki</reading>jikijiki sound (<ja>じき</ja>). Through its choking jikijiki sounds, it coughs up a gear. Wait. Is this a machine lion?
data.reading_hint: You're relieved! You don't know how to fix a choking, eye-stabbed lion, but you can absolutely fix a ROBOTIC one. Robots are fixable.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Just before saying something important, you take an <radical>arrow</radical> to the <radical>mouth</radical> which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you <kanji>know</kanji> with someone else.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being so surprised by this arrow. Then, think of all the things you know that need to be said and told to everyone. Maybe you have information about nuke codes. Maybe you have information that will save the President. Whatever it is, make sure you know important things that need to be said (but also things that people want to prevent you from saying, even if it means shooting you in the mouth with an arrow).
data.reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading <ja>ち</ja> we use the word "cheese."

One of the things you <kanji>know</kanji> is actually very strange but very important. The president's <reading>chee</reading>se (<ja>ち</ja>) has been poisoned and only you know. If you could just say something then maybe you could save him... but... you have an arrow in your mouth.
data.reading_hint: Try saying the words "cheese" with an arrow in your mouth. What would that sound like? Go ahead and pretend out loud.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>long</radical> radical and the <kanji>long</kanji> kanji are the same! 

This kanji also means <kanji>leader</kanji>, because the longer a person is, the better a leader they'll be. Or maybe it was... the longer they've been somewhere? Whatever, longness = leaderness, you know?
data.meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical long, you know the kanji long as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: You see a very <kanji>long</kanji> person. It's Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the <kanji>leader</kanji> of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou.
data.reading_hint: <kanji>Long</kanji> isn't an idea that's easy to imagine in any specific sense, but you can try some other things too, as long as it gets associated with Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading>. For the most part, when you see a kanji with the radical <ja>長</ja> the reading will be <ja>ちょう</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
There are some <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>knife</radical> in <kanji>front</kanji> of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.

This kanji means <kanji>before</kanji> too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all.
data.meaning_hint: Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care. Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run. Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're going crazy with these things in <kanji>front</kanji> of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a <reading>Zen</reading> (<ja>ぜん</ja>) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked!
data.reading_hint: Go ahead and do some Zen Buddhist meditation. Maybe it'll help you to remember this kanji's reading better (and calm your mind so you're ready for the next kanji!).

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cross</radical> you're holding above your <radical>head</radical> to keep your <radical>horns</radical> <radical>dry</radical> keeps pulling you <kanji>south</kanji>. Probably because it's warmer and less damp down south.
data.meaning_hint: Look down and see the compass pointing south and feel the cross pulling you in that direction.
data.reading_mnemonic: You finally make it down <kanji>south</kanji>, and it is dry, but you're really hungry. When you try to find southern food you realize every single store is only selling <reading>naan</reading> (<ja>なん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine being in the south and taking big bites of naan. It tastes good, but now your mouth is dry just like your horns. Too dry...

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>dirt</radical> you've made a <radical>roof</radical> over the <radical>ground</radical> where you can be in <radical>private</radical>. This is your <kanji>room</kanji>! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the room you live in now. Take away all the stuff and you're left with a roof and the dirt on the ground. It's your own little private place.
data.reading_mnemonic: The only problem with your <kanji>room</kanji> is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's <reading>shih tzu</reading> (<ja>しつ</ja>). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely.
data.reading_hint: Imagine watching the little shih tzu come into your room and lift its leg to all your things. This isn't fair. The shih tzu has its own room to pee in. Why does it have to ruin yours?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around to <radical>poop</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> you never know what could be happening <kanji>behind</kanji> you. <kanji>After</kanji> you're done you could turn <kanji>back</kanji> to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to loiter while you poop in the winter. You're just trying to take your time as you squat over the snow, but soon you hear things behind you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You finally look <kanji>behind</kanji> you and see <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (<ja>ご</ja>) and a giant <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> having a violent battle <kanji>back</kanji> there!
data.reading_hint: Godzilla and <ja>こういち</ja> were going at it behind you the entire time you were just lazily taking a poop in the snow?! Ahh, that's so embarrassing! And also dangerous, they could have crushed you! You should look behind you more.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>rice paddy</radical> you find a <radical>heart</radical> and it makes you <kanji>think</kanji>. You think a lot of things like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"
data.meaning_hint: Think, think, think. Think about this rice paddy heart.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>think</kanji> this heart is from a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). It's big and covered in wool. It's also baa-ing a little. Why would you think anything else?
data.reading_hint: Do you think you could tell if a heart is from a sheep or not? I think you could.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> that gives <radical>life</radical> is our very own <kanji>star</kanji> (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky and there are billions of them. I hope you don't feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>star</kanji> (the sun) and all of the others are yours to protect with your trusty <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>). If you could protect your land from the West, then you can certainly defend the stars too!
data.reading_hint: Now you're soaring through between the stars, swinging your saber through the silence of space, and... wait. No that was a dream. You roll over and pat your saber. The two of you are ready just in case the stars need your help.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> of <radical>tongue</radical>s is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... <kanji>lively</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Your entire body wakes up, you feel so lively! The tongues are making you more aware of yourself and your surroundings than you've ever been. You want to dance, you want to sing, you want to live your life.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>lively</kanji> feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the <reading>cats</reading> (<ja>かつ</ja>) in your neighborhood too!
data.reading_hint: You and the cats are running around playing together, because you can't seem to get the lively feelings to stop. You have to get the energy out, but the cats have sharp claws and they're scratching you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, so you point your <radical>gun</radical> out the <radical>window</radical> at it. "You better turn back, <kanji>sea</kanji>, or I'll shoot!"
data.meaning_hint: You'll have to think of the "sea" as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the "sea," not the "tsunami." It's like aiming for the head of a zombie and not the arms or legs.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sea</kanji> decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else.
data.reading_hint: Imagine paddling in your kayak, your gun still in one hand, as you chase the sea back to its home.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fortune</radical> <radical>boil</radical>s down to a single <kanji>point</kanji> in time. One <kanji>decimal point</kanji> in the math of time determines how the rest of your future will go.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine actually going somewhere to get your fortune told and watching a big boiling pot of goo. As it boils, it melts down to a single point at the very bottom. Where this point is determines your future.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the <kanji>decimal point</kanji> you watch in awe as it moves to the <reading>ten</reading> (<ja>てん</ja>) spot in a long series of numbers.
data.reading_hint: Is the ten spot good? Are you going to live a long life or does this point mean you're only going to live ten more years?! Ahh!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You scoop some <radical>grain</radical>s into a <radical>ladle</radical> to do <kanji>science</kanji>. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science <kanji>course</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine carefully ladling grains into different piles so you can do science experiments on them. This course is going to make you an expert. You'll be the best in this department!
data.reading_mnemonic: Using your <kanji>science</kanji> skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). This is the science <kanji>department</kanji>'s special car now!
data.reading_hint: From your science meddling, these grains grow huge, red, and sprout sports cars when they're ripe. This is the true power of science!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You come across an <radical>angel</radical> wearing a <radical>hat</radical> that's covered in <radical>flowers</radical>. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make <kanji>tea</kanji> out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though.
data.meaning_hint: How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*
data.reading_mnemonic: In your <kanji>tea</kanji> you find a little metal button. I guess you missed it while you turned the angel into tea. You look at the button - on the back it says "To <reading>Cha</reading>d, you'll make an awesome angel." Looks like you're drinking Chad the Angel.
data.reading_hint: It gets kind of weird when you know their names... Usually you just make them into tea without knowing who they are (easier that way). This one... this one is Chad, and you remember it vividly, because now you feel kind of bad.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>eat</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>eat</kanji> are the same! Lucky you.
data.meaning_hint: If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is <kanji>meal</kanji>. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know "eat" you should be able to remember "meal" as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: Thank goodness, you finally get to <kanji>eat</kanji> your <kanji>meal</kanji>. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a <reading>shock</reading> (<ja>しょく</ja>) from somewhere.
data.reading_hint: So, do you keep eating and keep getting shocked? Or do you not eat and continue to starve? What is worse? Obviously you're in one of the Saw movies, or something, too, so feel the fear. What will you choose? Life with shocks or death from hunger?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>neck</radical> and the kanji <kanji>neck</kanji> are exactly the same!
data.reading_mnemonic: The only thing you do with your <kanji>neck</kanji> is use it to swallow lots of <reading>coo</reading>l <reading>bea</reading>ns (<ja>くび</ja>). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there.
data.reading_hint: Look at yourself in a mirror as the cool beans make their way down your neck. You can see them, like little ants marching all the way down to your tummy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. <radical>Lack</radical> becomes <kanji>Lack</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: If you know the radical you know this.
data.reading_mnemonic:
To remember <ja>けつ</ja>, we use the word "ketsup." It's the perfect blend of ketchup and catsup!

You're <kanji>lack</kanji>ing something in your fridge. You look around, trying to find the <reading>ketsu</reading>p (<ja>けつ</ja>) you lack. You can't find it, because you lack it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine having to use regular, ordinary ketchup, or just old, boring catsup on your burger. Or even worse, an actual tomato. BLEH!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <kanji>family name</kanji>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <kanji>surname</kanji>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
data.meaning_hint: Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!
data.reading_mnemonic: Don't worry, I'll tell you where your <kanji>family name</kanji> came from. Your family used to herd <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). You read that right, your family was of the sheep clan because you took care of sheep all day.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your ancestors, herding sheep. Thanks to them your name means "sheep people." Thanks great great great great great grand pappy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A giant <radical>cross</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> stands above you. "I am <kanji>reason</kanji>!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.
data.meaning_hint: Because it's a cross with a mouth, it thinks that it is reason in all the chaos.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>reason</kanji> that this Cross of Reason exists is to combat the <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>) of the world, who just bring chaos into everything.
data.reading_hint: "Those youths just do things for no reason! That's why I, the Cross of Reason is here! I will knock some reason into those youths."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>umbrella</radical>, and it's holding it over his head, which is strange, because trees normally like water... turns out, it's not water falling on him, but dollar <kanji>bills</kanji> floating down.
data.meaning_hint: The sick part of this is that those dollar <kanji>bills</kanji> were once this tree's friends. The tree is sobbing uncontrollably as pieces of his friends fall on him and all around him - which is why he's using the umbrella to protect himself.
data.reading_mnemonic: The tree couldn’t take the body parts of his friends falling down on him, so he <reading>sat</reading> (<ja>さつ</ja>) down, and began crying uncontrollably.
data.reading_hint: What else could he do? He couldn’t move, so he sat. It’s weird imagining a tree trying to sit…

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>clan</radical> are a group of <kanji>people</kanji>. They are the <kanji>people</kanji> of a <kanji>nation</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The mouth clan are distinct peoples. They do, of course, use their mouths.
data.reading_mnemonic: The mouth clan <kanji>peoples</kanji> are a <kanji>nation</kanji> of <kanji>people</kanji> who use their mouths to say <reading>mean</reading> (<ja>みん</ja>) things to other peoples.
data.reading_hint: That's why they're the mouth clan. This nation of people are known for mouthing off and saying mean things. Imagine them, as a nation, saying mean things to you. How awful! All being from the same place, they're all into it too. In a way, they're not the mouth clan, they're the mean clan.

data.meaning_mnemonic: While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you take your <radical>sword</radical> and cut out an <kanji>area</kanji> on the ground. This whole place is your area now!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine riding your scooter around in a really large circle, pressing your sword into the ground as you do. Once you close the circle, you claim to everyone around that this is YOUR area, and they aren't allowed in.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you look down at your <kanji>area</kanji>, you suddenly realize there is a <reading>hen</reading> (<ja>へん</ja>) pecking at the ground in there. "Um, excuse me, hen, I believe I said this is MY area?!" You try to kick it out, but it hops over your leg.
data.reading_hint: Imagine doing everything you can to get this hen out of your area, but it manages to dodge and outwit you at every turn. You even slash at it with your sword and try to run it over with your scooter, but the hen can't be stopped. This is the hen's area now. You have been defeated.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have the measurement of a leader. Imagine yourself measuring said leader (his/her height) and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you <kanji>attach</kanji> another head to the top of his/her head.
data.meaning_hint: Make sure you really feel like the person can’t be a leader because they’re too short when you measure them (I know this isn’t true, but we’re remembering kanji here, anything goes!). As long as you feel disconcerted that the leader isn’t tall enough, you should be able to remember that you need to attach something to the leader to make him/her tall enough. The fact that you’re attaching another head to the top of his/her head is pretty weird too, and should help you to remember the meaning.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is <ja>つ</ja>. So, think of <kanji>attach</kanji>ing something to something else. What would you need? You'd need <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) things to put together!
data.reading_hint: Just focus on how attaching requires two things to remember this reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>lion</radical> drops a <radical>drop</radical> of saliva onto this <radical>person</radical> <kanji>from</kanji> above. The person is in a much worse place <kanji>compared with</kanji> where they were before, <kanji>since</kanji> they only just recently fell into this pit.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the person, the lion is leaning over them, the drop of spit dangling from their mouth. "I-I want to go back where I came from," the person gasps, shaking.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>From</kanji> above there is a loud caw, and a giant <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) swoops down, forcing the lion to back off. The eagle grabs the person with its talons, bringing him into the air! But now he's... in the air being carried by a giant eagle, <kanji>compared with</kanji> where he was before, is this really better?!
data.reading_hint: The eagle came from the sky and technically rescued him, but compared to where he was before, it may not be a better situation. I think this person is going to be eaten either way.

data.meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>slide</radical> is your <radical>husband</radical>'s only <kanji>fault</kanji>. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking out the window of your house and watching your husband slide down his slide over and over. He's not even good at it, he falls off the side halfway down most of the time. You want to complain, but he's pretty decent otherwise. This is his only fault.
data.reading_mnemonic: You try to come up with another <kanji>fault</kanji> of his so you can complain when you see a tiny <reading>shih tzu</reading> (<ja>しつ</ja>) trotting by. Oh no! Before you can call out, your husband has fallen off the slide and crushed the poor thing. You hear a sharp yelp and then nothing.
data.reading_hint: You run outside and yell, "AHA! It's your fault that shih tzu died! You and that stupid slide!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> coming out of the patient's <radical>heart</radical> is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for <kanji>certain</kanji> death.
data.meaning_hint: As you imagine the mad scientist drawing blood out of the patient's heart with a small slide, also imagine a little meter hooked up to him as well. On one end is "SURVIVE!" on the other end is "CERTAIN DEATH." Right now the finger is pointing close to <kanji>certain</kanji> death, though :(
data.reading_mnemonic: As the beeping heart thing starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the doctor puts his hands together and <reading>hits</reading> (<ja>ひつ</ja>) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.
data.reading_hint: Maybe imagine yourself running in there too, just trying to <reading>hit</reading> the patient back to life, because the patient was your friend.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're flying in a Jet. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "<kanji>Not yet</kanji>! Not yet! NOT YET!"
data.meaning_hint: Feel the irritation of this. How irritating is this kid going to be the whole flight over? The jet is going as fast as it can!
data.reading_mnemonic: What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is "<reading>Me</reading> (<ja>み</ja>) me me me me me me me me me me." Hate kids like that.
data.reading_hint: Go ahead and pretend to listen to the kid asking if we're there yet. Then in your mind go "me me me me me me me" quietly.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This kanji uses a modified <radical>jet</radical> radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the <kanji>end</kanji> of the earth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the end of the earth being like how they imagined it pre-Columbus era. Just a big drop going off into space, giant waterfalls plummeting down. Your crazy jet has made it to the very end! Congratulations!
data.reading_mnemonic: When you get to the <kanji>end</kanji> of the world, you land your jet and put out a few <reading>mats</reading> (<ja>まつ</ja>) to sit on so you can view the sights.
data.reading_hint: It's surprisingly dirty down here, because all the water takes the garbage this way. That's why you sit on these mats you brought.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Next to the <radical>tree</radical>, a <radical>lid</radical> is put on your <radical>father</radical>. "Hello child," he says. "This is your new <kanji>school</kanji>."
data.meaning_hint: He goes on to explain that he changed your school to here because there is a tree to block the satellite's view. Also, he wears a tin foil lid on his head so they can't track him. The regular school was no good because "they were watching." So now you have this new school, taught under a tree by your father who's wearing a lid on his head.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your new <kanji>school</kanji> has other students too. They are all <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>s, though.
data.reading_hint: On your first day of school, imagine walking under the tree and seeing all your classmates. They're all <ja>こういち</ja>–similar to each other, but with some variation. Your father explains these <ja>こういち</ja>s escaped from a government research facility, and they come to this school to receive a better education.  "These poor <ja>こういち</ja>s need a school that will teach them more than just kanji and Japanese vocabulary."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> <radical>leaf</radical> grows only in the <radical>winter</radical>. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the <kanji>summer</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Just think of the eye leaf as weird (it is weird, after all). It grows in the winter. Now, think of any normal leaves. They do the exact opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now it's summertime! What do you do during the <kanji>summer</kanji>? You just sit around with your favorite string tying <reading>knots</reading> (<ja>なつ</ja>) in it over and over again.
data.reading_hint: Think about summer. Now think about yourself tying knots. Now think about summer again. Now think about tying knots again. Now think about your mother getting upset at you because all you do is tie knots all summer long. Go play video games like a normal kid!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>pig</radical>. Your pig, because it's your <kanji>house</kanji>! You keep your pig inside where it's nice and warm. He's a member of your family, so he deserves to live in your <kanji>home</kanji> too.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the little pig, prancing around happily under the roof of your house.
data.reading_mnemonic: Also in your <kanji>house</kanji>, is your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). Your pig and your car are safe under your roof.
data.reading_hint: Picture the pig again, but this time sitting in your car, which is also in your house. The three of you are warm and cozy and safe together in your home.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have two <radical>bow</radical>s but they're both covered in <radical>ice</radical>. This has made them very <kanji>weak</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Just look at these weak, iced over bows. If you tried to draw back their strings they'd snap into a million pieces.
data.reading_mnemonic: You give up on your trip and bring the <kanji>weak</kanji> bows back to your car, but it's stuck in the ice and snow. You decide to use the bows as a <reading>jack</reading> (<ja>じゃく</ja>) to try to get your car unstuck. Unfortunately, they're just too weak and they break in half.
data.reading_hint: Now you're stuck with two weak broken bows and no jack. Ice is lame.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>sun</radical> is used in a <radical>temple</radical> to tell <kanji>time</kanji>. They don't have clocks or cell phones, they have sun dials and good old fashioned "looking up and seeing where the sun is right now."

This also can mean <kanji>o' clock</kanji>, as in "five o'clock" It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being in a temple and realizing you don't know what time it is. Never fear! Look on up at the sun. Ah, yes. Blinding noon.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Time</kanji> in a temple makes you think of <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>). Specifically, Jesus being able to perform time travel magic. He winks at you, goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth.
data.reading_hint: Imagine him going to all kinds of different times and also make sure you're specifically imagining Jesus doing all these things. Put these two together and you'll remember the reading in no time. (Haha, get it?)

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> that ties you to your <radical>clan</radical> is <kanji>paper</kanji>. Your papers, that is.
data.meaning_hint: The paper itself was also made by your clan using thread woven really tightly together.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need this specific <kanji>paper</kanji> to prove that you aren't a <reading>Commi</reading> (<ja>かみ</ja>), aka a Communist. Or that you are. It really depends on where you want to go and what decade this is.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a big guard coming up to you and asking to see your papers so they can see what clan you belong to. Well you're from the Commi clan, so you really hope this guard is okay with that.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> to <radical>oneself</radical> (yourself), you decide to <kanji>write down</kanji>. Whether this is in the form of a journal, diary, or blog, you feel the need to <kanji>record</kanji> these important thoughts in some way.
data.meaning_hint:
Just imagine writing in a diary and saying everything to write aloud to yourself in your head. 

"Dear me, today I learned a lot of new kanji on WaniKani. It was the best. I love the crabigator sooooo much. Love, me."
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to protect what you <kanji>write down</kanji> and <kanji>record</kanji> for yourself with a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). These are your special thoughts and feelings, you don't want anyone else to see! Lock them away with a key!
data.reading_hint: Picture the key you use to keep what you write down a secret. What does it look like? How does it feel in your hands?

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>scooter</radical> with your <radical>mama</radical> carrying a <radical>task</radical> she needs to get done. You see her <kanji>pass through</kanji>, hurrying by to get that task done.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine your mama passing through your house on a scooter, not stopping because she needs to get her task done urgently.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you watch your mama <kanji>pass through</kanji> the house, she yells, "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS TASK <reading>TOO</reading> (<ja>つう</ja>)!" Too?! Oh no, now you have to do it too. Hurry up!
data.reading_hint: Why do you have to do the task too? Because there are two tasks, so the two of you have to do them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>mouth</radical> and <radical>mustache</radical>, covering up all your talking holes. This is because you kept saying how <kanji>tall</kanji> and <kanji>expensive</kanji> you are.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself saying how tall and expensive you are to everyone in the room. Then they use a lid to cover your mouth so you can't talk to anyone anymore. But, then your mustache starts talking, saying the same thing. That's why this lid covers both your mustache and your mouth. Now you can't say that you are tall or expensive.
data.reading_mnemonic:
"I am <kanji>tall</kanji>er and more <kanji>expensive</kanji> than you." 

You're saying this because there are some <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>s in the room, and you want to make them feel inferior (you're a <ja>こういち</ja> hater). You keep comparing your height to the <ja>こういち</ja>s in the room, and you keep checking price tags. Then you tell them you're taller and more expensive than they are.
data.reading_hint: The <ja>こういち</ja>s finally get tired of your shenanigans, and lid up your mouth and mustache so you can't say that you're tall or expensive.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>private</radical> <radical>bow</radical> made of <radical>insect</radical>s that's extremely <kanji>strong</kanji>. Insect bodies are really durable, so they make for strong bows. You also have to be strong to use it, since it was made just for strong arms.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding this strong bow in your strong arms. Look closer at the little insect bodies that make it up. Thanks for your help, little guys.
data.reading_mnemonic: You had this <kanji>strong</kanji> bow made especially for you in <ja><reading>きょう</reading>と</ja>. <ja>きょうと</ja> is famous for their strong bows, so if you ever want another, you know where to go.
data.reading_hint: Imagine all the strong people who live in <ja>きょうと</ja> and make strong things. You should go there someday!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>teacher</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> is happiest because they get to <kanji>teach</kanji>! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a teacher excitedly teaching, bundled up in the cold. Snow falling outside. Grumpy children being taught inside.
data.reading_mnemonic: Teachers can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to <reading><ja>きょう</ja></reading><ja>と</ja>. <ja>きょうと</ja> is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the teaching teacher teaching you about Japan in <ja>きょうと</ja> in winter. You've always wanted to go to <ja>きょうと</ja>!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical>'s <radical>village</radical> is the <kanji>reason</kanji> he's king. Without the village there would be no reason to have a king in the first place.
data.meaning_hint: If a king has no one to rule then he has no reason to exist.
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't have <kanji>reason</kanji> without <reading>re</reading> (<ja>り</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Just like you can't have a king without a village, you can't have reason without re.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Sew <radical>thread</radical> through your <radical>top hat</radical> and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a <kanji>group</kanji> of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a group of people threaded together by their top hats. Don't you want to be part of a cool group like that? Your own top hat team.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>group</kanji> decides to make <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>) together. You take off your top hats and use them as soap molds, mixing together all of your favorite smells and colors.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being in a group of soap makers. Picture the soap bubbles floating between all of you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>boat</radical> has <radical>fins</radical> and a <radical>mouth</radical>! It's still a <kanji>boat</kanji> though.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this boat. It's still a boat, but there is a big mouth on the front and it has fins that it paddles forward with.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>boat</kanji> belongs to the <reading>cen</reading>taurs (<ja>せん</ja>). That's probably why you've never seen a boat like it before.
data.reading_hint: Picture this mouth and boat with a bunch of centaurs riding in it. Centaurs have a lot more parts than humans, so it makes sense that their boats have more parts (animal ones) too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use a <radical>scooter</radical> to travel the <radical>circumference</radical> of the world and it will take you a full <kanji>week</kanji>. Seven whole days!
data.meaning_hint: A week in earth time is also known as a "full scoot" in scooter lingo. ;)
data.reading_mnemonic: If you want to scoot for a <kanji>week</kanji>, you'll need <reading>shoe</reading>s. Good shoes too, not sandals or high heels or boots. Solid, high quality shoes, so you don't fall off the scooter and hurt yourself.
data.reading_hint: You can't ride a scooter for a week barefoot, are you nuts?! Get some shoes!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rain</radical> is hated so much by <radical>wolverine</radical>s, so they always want to live in the <kanji>snow</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine rain falling on a wolverine and how much they hate it, so the wolverine moves up north to somewhere with lots of snow.
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask the wolverine, "Why do you want this <kanji>snow</kanji> so bad?" He replies quickly: "Because the rain is <reading>yucky</reading>" (<ja>ゆき</ja>).
data.reading_hint: He keeps saying "Yucky yucky yucky" over and over again. Imagine him doing this with an accent that would bring the word closer to <ja>ゆき</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>fish</radical> and the kanji <kanji>fish</kanji> are exactly the same!
data.meaning_hint: Nothing fishy about that, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: You catch a <kanji>fish</kanji>. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: "GO!" (<ja>ぎょ</ja>). "GO GYO GYO GYO!" There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you.
data.reading_hint: Have him continue to scream "GO GYO GYO GYO!" as you try to get your engine started and attempt to flee your impending doom. The fish helps too, because he's pretty worried as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bird</radical> radical and the <kanji>bird</kanji> kanji are the same!
data.meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical bird you know the kanji bird.
data.reading_mnemonic: Think of a run of the mill <kanji>bird</kanji>, whatever comes to mind for you first is fine. Then, your lovely bird swells. The shape of a face, then a hand, start stretching the bird apart until it explodes outward. Covered in blood and feathers is Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: After bursting out of this bird, she turns her head sharply in your direction. "I don't just own the streets, I own the birds too. I'm inside every bird, and I, Mrs Chou, can burst out at any time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>yellow</radical> and the kanji <kanji>yellow</kanji> are exactly the same!
data.reading_mnemonic: You're in a room, surrounded completely by <kanji>yellow</kanji>. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape.
data.reading_hint: The walls are coming in closer, too. Make sure you feel a bit of peril as you look for this key. The walls have a slight opening at the bottom too, so if you don't find it before the wall goes over it, the key will be lost forever, and you'll be smushed!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>black</radical> and the kanji <kanji>black</kanji> are exactly the same.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're in a completely <kanji>black</kanji> room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's <reading>Coke</reading> (<ja>こく</ja>)! Mm, tasty Coke.
data.reading_hint: You need to drink all this Coke, otherwise you're going to drown. Drink this Coke and keep tasting its cold sweetness as you drink it all to survive.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>branch</radical> radical and the <kanji>branch</kanji> kanji are the same! This kanji also means <kanji>support</kanji>. To remember it, think about a tree with lots of branches. The branches support each other and the trunk of the tree. If you were to climb the tree, the branches would be able to support your weight too!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a branch supporting the weight of you, your entire family, and maybe a few friends.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're happily sitting on this <kanji>branch</kanji>, letting it <kanji>support</kanji> all this weight, when a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) starts to climb the tree. A very, very big sheep. Uh oh... no no, sheep. If you get on this branch it won't be able to support all this weight!!!
data.reading_hint:
The big sheep walks up the side of the tree with its weird hooves and starts to put its weight on the branch. "No no no!" you and your whole family scream. The branch can't support the weight of the sheep. It snaps! You all tumble to the ground.

The end.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>master</radical>s gets the biggest <kanji>dwelling</kanji>. He <kanji>reside</kanji>s in a huge mansion on the top of the mountain, surrounded by all the other masters in their smaller dwellings.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the leader master's big, beautiful dwelling. Everyone else is jealous.
data.reading_mnemonic: He needs this big <kanji>dwelling</kanji> so he has somewhere to store all of his <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>). Masters always have lots of fancy, expensive things, and he has jewels.
data.reading_hint: Imagine opening the door to the leader master's dwelling and thousands of jewels come pouring out, whisking you off, down the mountain.

data.meaning_mnemonic: With <radical>top hat</radical> <radical>power</radical>, you're able to <kanji>help</kanji> anyone.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting on your top hat and getting power from it. Then, you use that power to help someone. It's important to make the association that it's the top hat giving you the power to help that person. You're basically Frosty the Snow Man.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person you <kanji>help</kanji> with your top hat power? It's <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (<ja>じょ</ja>).
data.reading_hint:
You can imagine saving her however you like. Perhaps she was under a car, and you used your top hat powers to help her out of that situation by lifting it above your head.

Note: Jo-Anne is the character we're using with <ja>じょ</ja> reading mnemonics. She is short compared to Jourm (<ja>じょう</ja>), the giant farmhand, which is how you'll differentiate the two similar readings.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're in a <radical>cage</radical> and you've been shot by an <radical>arrow</radical>. Obviously things are looking pretty bad. You need some <kanji>medicine</kanji> if you hope to live.
data.meaning_hint: More specifically, antibiotics. Your wound is festering pretty badly.
data.reading_mnemonic:
When we need to remember the sound <ja>い</ja> we use the word "Eagle."

You need your <kanji>medicine</kanji> really bad. Then, you look up. There's an <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) flying overhead. He has a package. It's medicine! You're saved!
data.reading_hint: Or, so you think. He just keeps circling and circling. Feel some hate for the eagle. Why isn't he dropping the medicine? You don't have long to live!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>wolverine</radical> is going down a <radical>slide</radical> into your <radical>mouth</radical>. Why is he going into your mouth, though? You're opening it really wide, because you're screaming "<kanji>BUDDY</kanji>!!! You're so excited to see your wolverine buddy-pal again. You thought he was dead.
data.meaning_hint: Make sure you feel super happy. Even yell "Buddy" out loud while imagining this wolverine coming at you, if you're not in a quiet-zone.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you're about to embrace your <kanji>buddy</kanji> wolverine, a rac<reading>coon</reading> tackles the wolverine off the slide, preventing your mouth embrace.
data.reading_hint: "RaCCOON!" you yell. "THIS IS NONE OF YOUR BUSINESS. Get out of here." Feel some hate for the raccoon. He ruined everything.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want to take a <radical>measurement</radical> of what you're <radical>writing</radical> to make sure it's long enough to hand in to your professor, when you realize it's the <kanji>opposite</kanji> of what you should be doing. You don't measure writing, you check things like word count and page numbers. Now it's going to be you <kanji>versus</kanji> the teacher on who determines how long this thing you're writing should be.
data.meaning_hint: Okay. It's going to be you versus the teacher. Subject? Measuring physical length versus checking word count.
data.reading_mnemonic: You let your nerves get the better of you and right when it's about to be you <kanji>versus</kanji> your professor, you hand him a new <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). Is this also the <kanji>opposite</kanji> of what you should be doing? Probably, since it's bribery. But no one can say no to a tie, right?
data.reading_hint: Next to your nicely measured writing, tape a brand new tie with a sticky note that says, "I hope this isn't the opposite of what you want, because I really need this A."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your nation's <radical>flag</radical> sits on top of a <radical>cape</radical>d <radical>mouth</radical>. This is the symbol for the "<kanji>Bureau</kanji> of Secret Things." It's a special <kanji>department</kanji> of your government made to keep things hidden.
data.meaning_hint: The cape covering the mouth represents how this bureau never talks about their secrets. The flag represents your country. Think about all the cool secret things the Bureau of Secret Things must have.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>bureau</kanji>'s best-kept secret is cloaking devices that <reading>cloak you</reading> (<ja>きょく</ja>) with the press of a button.
data.reading_hint: Now, this mnemonic isn’t perfectly close, but the goal is to get you close enough in your brain so that you can remember <ja>きょく</ja> later. If you can get to CLOAK YOU, then you can get to <ja>きょく</ja> much easier than just trying to get there from scratch. So imagine working in this bureau and getting to cloak yourself all the time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around with a <radical>weapon</radical> because you're currently doing your <kanji>service</kanji> and <kanji>duty</kanji> to your country. You're standing guard outside, waiting just in case something will happen.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine standing around with a weapon in your hands. It feels more like you're doing nothing, loitering around the wall, but this is how you offer your service to your country, so you have to do it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're about halfway through your <kanji>service</kanji>, when a <reading>yak</reading> (<ja>やく</ja>) walks by. It stops directly in front of you and grunts. "Excuse me, Mr. Yak, but it's my <kanji>duty</kanji> to escort you away from my country."
data.reading_hint: Somehow your duty has become pushing this stubborn, hairy yak away from the entrance to your country. You poke it in the butt with your weapon, but it doesn't seem to care.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>fingers</radical> is a <radical>weapon</radical>, so you <kanji>throw</kanji> it. Maybe you're angry and you threw the weapon at a person you don't like. Maybe you're a pacifist and you threw it away so no one else could use it. Either way, when you have a weapon in your fingers you have to throw it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a weapon in between your fingers. It doesn't matter what kind. Now feel the weight as you throw it.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>throw</kanji> your weapon away because you're about to enter <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja> and there are no weapons allowed there. There is, however, a big pile of thrown away weapons by the border, which is where you're throwing yours right now.
data.reading_hint: Imagine throwing the weapon in your fingers just before you walk into <ja>とうきょう</ja>. You can see the lights, smell the smells! Throw your weapons and your cares away!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have at your disposal a <radical>tsunami</radical> and a <radical>hook</radical> to assassinate this <radical>person</radical>. Which weapon will you choose. <kanji>Decide</kanji> now!
data.meaning_hint: Have trouble with the decision. Which one? Tsunami will be big and cool, but a hook will be more discreet. How can you decide? Can you think of a neat way to decide this, like Two-Face on Batman?
data.reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading <ja>けつ</ja> we always use the word "ketsup." It's a special mix of ketchup and catsup (yum!)

You finally <kanji>decide</kanji>. You're going to go with the tsunami... but not just any tsunami. You'll kill him with a tsunami of <reading>ketsu</reading>p (<ja>けつ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Get everything ready to take your target down. How will you plan this? Where will you put it? Go ahead and watch your plan unfurl, too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You dig <radical>nine</radical> <radical>hole</radical>s for your <kanji>research</kanji>. You should always do research with nine variables so you can compare them and so there's an uneven number.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine carefully digging nine holes so you can do your research. Hmm, I wonder what kind of research these holes are for...
data.reading_mnemonic: You are <kanji>research</kanji>ing <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (<ja>きゅう</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Put nine full grown cucumbers into their holes so you can research what happens next.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The self radical is a bit modified, with things sticking out, but that’s because it’s falling down a slide.

Sure, it’s your<radical>self</radical> who’s tumbling down the <radical>slide</radical>… at least that’s how it feels to you. Who are you? What are you? All you know is you’re <kanji>somebody</kanji>, but you don’t know who that somebody is.
data.meaning_hint: Apparently, you’re having some kind of internal crisis. Come up with a rough one and you’ll remember this kanji better.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re falling down this metaphorical slide… And then you hit something… and you hit it really hard. It’s your metaphorical <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>). You split it in half and it’s at a right angle. The pain is incredible (shins have a lot of nerves!). It may have been broken, and you may not be able to walk correctly again… metaphorically speaking, that is.
data.reading_hint: Just make the tumble and shin hit as painful as possible in your imagination and you’ll surely remember this kanji’s on’yomi.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>coffin</radical> has been left out in the <radical>sun</radical> for too long. When dead bodies are out in the sun like this, they really begin to decompose. You are wondering who this person is, though. You can't tell because it's fallen apart too much. You look on the coffin. There's a label, but it only says "<kanji>someone</kanji>."
data.meaning_hint: Smell the stench of the decomposing body. Also, feel really curious as to who this person is. It came from somewhere that gives you a reason to believe it's someone you know. Then, feel the disappointment as you read the label that says "someone" instead of an actual name. "Someone," you repeat. "Someone."
data.reading_mnemonic:
To remember the sound <ja>しゃ</ja> we use "shaman."

It's time you open the coffin and check. Maybe there's more answers in there. There's no way this person could just be "<kanji>someone</kanji>." You lift the lid, and sure enough, you're able to figure out who it is. It's a <reading>sha</reading>man (<ja>しゃ</ja>), dressed in full shaman garb.
data.reading_hint: How strange that a shaman was delivered to you this way! Come up with a story explaining why this shaman's body is here at your door, rotting in the sun. Make it ridiculous and interesting so you remember it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>stone</radical> <radical>lantern</radical> is an excellent way to <kanji>sharpen</kanji> anything, even in the dark. Your knives, your forks, your spoons, and even your sword.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking around at night and you need to sharpen your sword. You walk up to a stone lantern and rub your sword all over it to sharpen it. Touch the blade. Indeed, it's been sharpened!
data.reading_mnemonic: Why did you <kanji>sharpen</kanji> your blade? Because you are about to do battle with <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>), the famous samurai warrior.
data.reading_hint:
You'll want to remember this character, because he will come up many times throughout your WaniKani journey. Ken the samurai used to work for WaniKani, but then he went rogue because he thought WaniKani wasn't being radical enough. So now he wanders the website carrying his squid friend (who you'll meet later) in a bucket.

To help you visualize him, imagine a samurai with armor made from crab shells, a helmet that is just an alligator head, and swords with crab claw hand guards. His great beard and mustache are styled in the shape of whatever kanji is giving you the most trouble at the time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>horse</radical> radical and the <kanji>horse</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
data.reading_mnemonic: You are looking at a horse. It's looking at you. You try making horse noises at it, to get a reaction. Instead of reacting with a normal horse noise, it just makes sheep noises: "<reading>Baaa</reading>," (<ja>ば</ja>) it says. "Baaaaa."
data.reading_hint: Feel the shock of this. It sounds just like a sheep, it's strange.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is just the <radical>tree</radical> radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means "<kanji>forest</kanji>."
data.meaning_hint: Makes sense, because a bunch of individual trees is what makes up a forest!
data.reading_mnemonic: One tree? No. Two trees? Not enough. I want <reading>more</reading> (<ja>もり</ja>) trees, please!
data.reading_hint: Keep repeating this pattern over and over, continually focusing in on how you need "more" trees to make this forest. For some reason the person working with you only goes up by one at a time, though, so you have to say it a lot (it'll help you to remember, anyways!).

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dirt</radical> makes it <radical>easy</radical> to identify your <kanji>location</kanji>. If you know that, you can go from <kanji>place</kanji> to place.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking at the dirt. It's a distinct color and texture, and you're able to identify your location just from that alone.
data.reading_mnemonic: Knowing your <kanji>location</kanji> from dirt is quite a feat! Who taught you that? It was <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>), the big local farmhand. Despite being a bit weird, he does really know his dirt and can tell you the <kanji>place</kanji> from which any dirt came.
data.reading_hint: Remember Jourm? He's our local farmhand who only has nine toes (from the <ja>上</ja> mnemonic). Imagine that guy explaining to you how to know your location from dirt. He may be a bit clumsy, but the man really does know his dirt.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the top of the <radical>sun</radical> and another <radical>cross</radical> sticking out the bottom. The <radical>moon</radical> is off to the right. That's because it's the <kanji>morning</kanji>, which is when the sun and moon switch over. Those crosses are making sure the sun stays high in the sky for the rest of the day.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a sun attached up in the sky with two crosses, which act as scaffolding, and the moon gradually fading off to the right as the morning wears on.
data.reading_mnemonic: Every <kanji>morning</kanji> you have <reading>Asa</reading>hi (<ja>あさ</ja>) beer for breakfast.
data.reading_hint: You watch the sun scaffolded by crosses, and the moon next to it, as you sip on your early-morning Asahi.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>sickle</radical> the <radical>rice paddy</radical> today because it's your <kanji>turn</kanji>. This kanji also means <kanji>number in a series</kanji>, which is a lot like a turn. For example, you're number 3, so your turn will be number 3.
data.meaning_hint:
Go through in your mind the system your farm / village uses for deciding who has to sickle on any given day. It rotates, and it's a turn-based system. So, do you all stand in a line? Is there a calendar? Come up with something interesting, focusing on your turn in the process you come up with. 

 It will be helpful to remember both the "number in a series" and "turn" meanings for the vocab coming up in the future.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>turn</kanji>-based rice sickle system is a contest as well! But, you are disappointed to find out that you have been <reading>ban</reading>ned from the game because of the performance enhancing steroids you've been taking.
data.reading_hint: Try to feel disappointed by this. Strange thing to feel disappointed by, but you were a great sickler. You were going to win the great prize, too (come up with something huge!), but now you're banned for the season.

data.meaning_mnemonic: "Does the <radical>bamboo</radical> shirt <radical>suit</radical> me?" you ask... but nobody will <kanji>answer</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Shout "PLEASE ANSWER ME!" a few times to get the idea of "answer" in your head. What you really want is an answer, whether it's bad or good, but nobody's willing to say anything because you look so terrible.
data.reading_mnemonic: You pull out a <reading>quarter</reading> (<ja>こた</ja>) and offer it to whoever will give you an <kanji>answer</kanji>.
data.reading_hint: With this shiny quarter in your hand, everyone is giving you their answer. Yay for bribery!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Using just <radical>thread</radical> <radical>meeting</radical> the paper (with a little ink on the end) you create a masterpiece of a <kanji>drawing</kanji> (or a <kanji>painting</kanji>).
data.meaning_hint: It's unbelievable the kind of drawing you're able to draw with just the tip of a thread. So much detail. So artistic. If it helps, imagine that you drew the Mona Lisa, better than the original, only using this floppy thread tool.
data.reading_mnemonic: You tell someone that you drew this <kanji>drawing</kanji> only using a thread. Their response? "<reading>EH</reading>?!?!?" (<ja>え</ja>)
data.reading_hint: Tell a few more people how you drew this. Have them all do the same "Eh!!??" reaction.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are some <radical>shellfish</radical> in a <radical>net</radical> that you can <kanji>buy</kanji>. You can't just buy loose shellfish. You can only buy the ones that are in the net, bagged up and ready for your money.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine looking over a bunch of different kinds of shellfish wrapped in nets. Think about which ones you want to buy.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to <kanji>buy</kanji> as many shellfish as you can fit in your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). You keep buying until your car is completely full of shellfish before you stop. Cars are totally a realistic unit of measure.
data.reading_hint: Imagine buying an entire car's worth of shellfish. Mmm delicious.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Aim the <radical>scooter</radical>'s <radical>neck</radical> at the <kanji>road</kanji>! Scooters are only meant for driving on <kanji>street</kanji>s and <kanji>path</kanji>s, and if you go the wrong <kanji>way</kanji>, you'll probably break your own neck!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine riding your scooter down the road. You're carefully aiming the scooter's neck the right way so you don't end up going out of control and dying.
data.reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading <ja>どう</ja> we use the word "doughnut."

You're traveling down this <kanji>road</kanji> so fast that you don't see the giant <reading>dou</reading>ghnut (<ja>どう</ja>) that's rolling toward you until the last minute. You crash into it, and both you and the doughnut go tumbling down. Ahg, your neck!
data.reading_hint: Alternate ending: You do a sweet jump, go right through the doughnut hole, take a bite, and land safely back onto the road!

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>gate</radical> that the <radical>sun</radical> goes through at a regular <kanji>interval</kanji>. There is an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> in the sense that the sun goes through it at the same time every day. And there is an <kanji>interval of space</kanji> in the sense that it has to go through the space between the gate posts.
data.meaning_hint: "Interval" is a weird word to remember, but just think of the sun going around the earth and through the gate like clockwork. Every 24 hours it passes through the gate, and each interval is exactly the same.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This method of keeping track of <kanji>interval</kanji>s of time was invented by the great Khans of Mongolia, specifically the most famous Khan of all: Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>).

Genghis Khan has had a huge impact on the world as we know it, especially the Eurasian continent of the past, so he's going to come up a lot from now on. Be prepared to get very familiar with him and his friends!
data.reading_hint: Picture Genghis Khan ordering his most skilled inventors and builders to create this special sun gate so they can harness the power of intervals, and all people under his rule can benefit from the accurate telling of time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>rain</radical> <radical>cloud</radical> is still a <kanji>cloud</kanji>! It's probably going to rain on you soon though, so I hope you have a jacket or an umbrella.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of the different types of clouds in the sky. There are puffy white ones, heavy dark ones, and wispy thin ones. But they're all clouds.
data.reading_mnemonic: You lie down and try to figure out what the <kanji>cloud</kanji>s are shaped like. The first cloud is shaped... like a <reading>coo</reading>l <reading>mo</reading>m (<ja>くも</ja>). She's wearing high pants, and holding a kid on each hip, but she's also listening to the latest music and using slang. Huh. You look to the next cloud and see... wait, another cool mom?
data.reading_hint: You look at each cloud and each one is a different cool mom. They're each doing different cool mom things. You suddenly don't want to look at the clouds anymore.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>winter</radical>, the <radical>woman</radical> has to go through all the <radical>rice</radical> and <kanji>count</kanji> each individual grain. Once she's counted all of them, she'll have an <kanji>amount</kanji> / <kanji>number</kanji> so that she can split them up accordingly.
data.meaning_hint: She has to count each grain out in order to divvy up the supply to last through the winter. Imagine yourself getting just a few grains today for food. It's not a good time for you guys :(
data.reading_mnemonic: Why are you so low on rice? It's because someone <reading>sue</reading>d your farm and took everything you owned. So, you had barely enough rice (or not enough).
data.reading_hint: Come up with a story about why your farm got sued for everything. Go to the court  case. Listen to the judge come up with your verdict. Be angry. This has ruined everything.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>white</radical> <radical>ice</radical> <radical>tree</radical> is a magical tree. When you eat its ice flowers it gives you incredible amounts of <kanji>comfort</kanji>, <kanji>ease</kanji>, and <kanji>pleasure</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself picking the white ice flowers off the tree. Then, put it in your mouth. Make it taste comforting... It puts you at ease. Then, swallow it. Feel your head go nuts with comfort. This is the greatest drug in the world when it comes to comfort. So much pleasure!
data.reading_mnemonic: You want more of this, You gather as much as you can, and create an entire <reading>rack</reading> (<ja>らく</ja>) at your store with this tree. You sell out immediately, and have to refill your rack.
data.reading_hint: Imagine setting up the rack. Make it look beautiful. Shift around the flowers. Fill up the entire rack. Of course, your focus should be on the rack portion.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Say</radical> it with your <radical>tongue</radical>. If you do, you'll be able to <kanji>talk</kanji>. You'll be able to <kanji>speak</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Your problem is you weren't saying it with your tongue before. Once you start using your tongue, you're able to speak suddenly!
data.reading_mnemonic: If something uses their tongue, it will be able to <kanji>talk</kanji> and <kanji>speak</kanji>. To prove this, you teach a <reading>wa</reading>lrus (<ja>わ</ja>) to use its tongue, and lo and behold, it speaks to you!
data.reading_hint: You decided to teach a walrus how to speak because it seemed like the hardest thing to teach, with its tusks and all that. It turned out to be really easy. Although, you may have picked the Justin Long walrus, by accident. Either way, this walrus can speak! And you definitely (probably) helped.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're standing in the middle of a <radical>rice paddy</radical> in the <radical>rain</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical>. You're standing here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by <kanji>electricity</kanji> (aka lightning) to show that it exists.
data.meaning_hint: Get hit by the electricity. How does it feel?
data.reading_mnemonic: After the <kanji>electricity</kanji> hits you, you feel your face. In it is a huge <reading>den</reading>t.
data.reading_hint: Feel the indent in your face. It doesn't hurt, strangely, but it is pretty huge. Panic about this dent a bit.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're taking an <radical>axe</radical> to a <radical>door</radical>. You're absolutely crazy. "I HATE THIS <kanji>PLACE</kanji>!!" you keep yelling as you smash in the door.
data.meaning_hint: Why do you hate this place, in particular? Come up with a great reason why to help you to remember this very broad kanji meaning.
data.reading_mnemonic: You finally break through the door and jump in. Inside is a great circus <reading>show</reading> (<ja>しょ</ja>). There are elephants, tightrope walkers, bears on unicycles, and more! The greatest show on earth, but why is it here at this <kanji>place</kanji>?
data.reading_hint: Come up with a weird reason as to why the circus is at this place you hate so much. Why did you come here with your axe? Does it have something to do with the circus show?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put a <radical>cross</radical> in the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>wolverine</radical>. What a strange <kanji>action</kanji>. Why would you do such a <kanji>thing</kanji>? The fact of the <kanji>matter</kanji> is that you're not too sure why you put that cross in the wolverine's mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that poor wolverine standing in front of you looking confused, with a cross in its mouth.
data.reading_mnemonic: This action doesn't impress <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>), who appears and gently removes the cross from the wolverine's mouth.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Jesus gently taking the cross out of the wolverine's mouth. What a swell dude.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A good <radical>leader</radical> can put the <radical>ground</radical>'s <radical>history</radical> to great <kanji>use</kanji>. You are a good leader. You have studied the ground and dirt of the earth your entire life. You know the history of the ground and you know how to use it to lead your people.
data.meaning_hint: Smell the ground. Waft the earthy smell of history into your leader-like nostrils. What does it smell like? It smells useful. And also like ground.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>use</kanji> the ground to raise <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). When you were down there sniffing around you realized that your people will flourish best if you use this land for grazing and raising sheep.
data.reading_hint: When you use the ground for sheep like this, your people rejoice. You're the best leader ever! You always use everything to your advantage!

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <radical>eye</radical> and <radical>fins</radical> litter the <radical>ground</radical>. What happened? You killed a fish. You must hide the murder <kanji>tool</kanji> before someone finds out it was you.
data.meaning_hint: You feel the panic upon realizing what you've just done. This is murder in the first degree. You used a terrible tool to do it, and now you must hide it.
data.reading_mnemonic: There’s <reading>goo</reading> (<ja>ぐ</ja>) all over your hands. Goopy goo. It’s the guts of the fish you just killed and it’s dripping off of the <kanji>tool</kanji> as well. Yuck.
data.reading_hint: That goo is really slimy. It’s disgusting. You feel sick to your stomach. Please don’t throw up, there’s already enough junk on the ground with the eye and fins and all.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You’re sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and someone <radical>cleat</radical>s you in the <radical>forehead</radical> as part of an <kanji>accept</kanji>ance ritual. It’s for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. You got knocked off the stool, and the cleats really hurt your forehead, but you’re just glad to have been accepted.

This kanji also means <kanji>receive</kanji>, which is quite similar to accept. It shouldn't be too hard to remember.
data.meaning_hint: You’re dealing with a lot of mixed emotions right now. You feel the pain from being cleated in the forehead and knocked clean off your stool, but you’re also glad to have finally been accepted into the soccer club. Suppress your pain. Accept this honor.
