data.reading_mnemonic: After you've been <kanji>accept</kanji>ed, they give you a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (<ja>じゅ</ja>) box to help you recover from the trauma of getting kicked. And you receive it with grace.
data.reading_hint: Did you ever play soccer as a kid? Do you remember accepting a small juice box into your little kid hands during halftime? Apparently pros drink the same ones.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When everyone has <radical>grain</radical> in their <radical>mouth</radical>, you will have <kanji>peace</kanji>. That is the <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> of doing things.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine Japanese people with grain in their mouth. The whole country is at peace.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Peace</kanji> is the <kanji>Japanese style</kanji>. The <reading>wa</reading>lruses (<ja>わ</ja>) living off of Japan see this, and start to emulate.
data.reading_hint: The walruses also achieve peace by putting grain in every walrus' mouth, following the Japanese style.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you give a <radical>woman</radical> a <radical>machine</radical> she'll <kanji>begin</kanji> learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to <kanji>start</kanji> before anyone else could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a woman seeing a new machine and beginning work on it right away to see how she can start it up.
data.reading_mnemonic: Actually, before she can <kanji>begin</kanji>, she has to shear the <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) over there. The machine is going to turn wool into yarn, but you can't just start that process by shoving the sheep in there. You have to keep the little sheep safe!
data.reading_hint: Picture a machine starting up as the woman begins to shear the sheep. Picture the sheep staring at you, staring at it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>roof</radical> is <radical>correct</radical> only if you <kanji>determine</kanji> that it is.
data.meaning_hint:
Imagine looking at a roof, and someone asks you, "Is this roof correct?"

"I determine it is."
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>determine</kanji>d it, but you still have to test this determination. You go to the top and roll a <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tot down the roof. Tater tots will only roll down a perfectly correct roof.
data.reading_hint: "Because of my tater tot roof test, I have once again determined it is correct."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Climb onto the <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>spring</radical> to see the <kanji>truth</kanji>. The world is waking back up from winter and revealing the <kanji>reality</kanji> of what it is all around you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine sitting comfortably on your roof as the world around you changes to spring. Snow melts and reveals all of the truths that have been obscured and hidden in winter.
data.reading_mnemonic: At the moment, you're trying to learn the <kanji>truth</kanji> about the deer that is coming out of the snowy woods when you see not one, but two baby deer appear with it! <reading>Gee! Two</reading> (<ja>じつ</ja>) babies! You keep looking around and realize that all of the animals seem to have two babies that they had hidden in the snow.
data.reading_hint: Gee! Two babies! Reality sure is lovely.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>stamp</radical> on the <radical>stool</radical> in front of you and use it on all of your <kanji>clothes</kanji>. Now even if you sell or lose a piece of <kanji>clothing</kanji>, you'll be able to find it again by checking for your special moon stamp.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine placing each piece of clothing you own onto the stool and carefully stamping them with a symbol of the moon. This should stop people from stealing all of your clothes!
data.reading_mnemonic: A few days later you're with a friend when you recognize the <kanji>clothes</kanji> they're wearing. You grab it, rip it off, and scream, "<reading>F**k</reading> (<ja>ふく</ja>) you!" There is your moon stamp! These are your clothes!!
data.reading_hint: Your friend turns red and tries to pull the clothes back, "F**k you!" they yell. "No, f**k you, these are my clothes and I have proof this time!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> is going to last an <radical>eternity</radical> you better learn how to <kanji>swim</kanji> now. We'll be under water for the rest of time and if you can't swim you're not gonna make it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture most of the earth's population already swimming on the tsunami that will last the rest of eternity. Your floaties and life preservers would help you through this mess. You need to swim!
data.reading_mnemonic: <reading>Oy</reading> (<ja>およ</ja>)! Oy, stop daydreaming about <kanji>swim</kanji>ming and actually do it!
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself swimming in the tsunami with everyone else. You can't really talk to them, you're too busy swimming for your life, so you just shout "Oy!" to them and they shout it back.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>wing</radical>ed <radical>cow</radical> is flying in the air. What a strange <kanji>thing</kanji>! You’ve heard of flying pigs before, but cows? This is a new and strange thing indeed! Cows with wings! What a silly thing to imagine.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if cows could fly. Wouldn’t you be jealous of them? I mean, if a cow can fly, any old thing should be able to, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: You want a <kanji>thing</kanji> to help you fly with the cow so you put on your flying <reading>boots</reading> (<ja>ぶつ</ja>). Your flying boots are a pretty strange thing in themselves, but they're the only way you can keep up.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a thing like flying boots. Do you believe such a thing could be real?

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Old</radical> <radical>flowers</radical> are <kanji>suffering</kanji> because they're old.
data.meaning_hint: Old things go through a lot of suffering because their bodies are breaking down. Flowers are no different from you and me.
data.reading_mnemonic: If an old flower (or person) is <kanji>suffering</kanji>, give them a <reading>coo</reading>kie (<ja>く</ja>).
data.reading_hint: No one can resist a good cookie. It will ease your suffering, or at least distract you for a little bit.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Sometimes <radical>life</radical> gives you a <radical>kick</radical>, and you have to <kanji>express</kanji> yourself to deal with it!
data.meaning_hint: Think of the last time life gave you a kick, and how you expressed that pain to make it go away.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>express</kanji> yourself, so you call up a friend and say “Heyo!” (<ja>ひょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself saying it more like <ja>ひょう</ja>, though, so your friend has to try to figure out what you're saying.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>clown</radical> <radical>building</radical> is over in that <kanji>part</kanji> of town. We keep the clown part as separate as we can from the rest of the normal people. In fact, the entire clown education <kanji>department</kanji> and their clown <kanji>club</kanji>s have to stay in their part, they can't come in ours.
data.meaning_hint: Of course, we feel terrible about forcing the clowns into their own part of town. It's not that they're lesser than us, it's just that we don't like them.
data.reading_mnemonic: You see, that <kanji>part</kanji> of town is full of <reading>boo</reading>ze (<ja>ぶ</ja>). Clowns need a lot of booze to keep their charade going, so we just let them have it. But they aren't allowed in our part anymore, because they all stink of nasty clown booze.
data.reading_hint: Picture all of the clowns, trapped in their weird clown part of town, drinking booze and smashing each other over the heads with the bottles. You're glad you don't live in that part.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You put a grain in your mouth and let it take a ride. This kanji has the same radicals as 和, but this time the grain is in your mouth, which is why there's little pieces of grain sticking out of the 口 part ;)
data.meaning_hint: Just imagine you're a car or a train and the grain is a person. It's going for a nice ride in your mouth!
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide the grain is probably lonely on this <kanji>ride</kanji> alone, so you add some <reading>no</reading>ri (<ja>の</ja>) seaweed, so it has a friend.
data.reading_hint: Now the nori is going for a ride too, woohoo!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under your <radical>roof</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> there are more <radical>mouth</radical>s to feed because you let <kanji>guest</kanji>s stay with you when it's cold. Some of them aren't family, so they have to pay to stay under your roof and get food. Those are <kanji>customer</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of the hungry guests and customers under your roof, eating your food and sleeping on your floor.
data.reading_mnemonic: One of your <kanji>guest</kanji>s is a regular named <reading>Kyaku</reading> (<ja>きゃく</ja>) the <kanji>customer</kanji>. Kyaku is always staying over at one place or another, so everyone knows their name.
data.reading_hint: Kyaku looks just like any other customer. Picture a stereotypical "customer" type person in your head.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Some of your <radical>private</radical> <radical>dirt</radical> is on the <radical>ground</radical>, so you stick a <radical>flag</radical> into it. Then on this private land you claimed, you build a <kanji>roof</kanji>. Under the roof you also build some <kanji>shop</kanji>s and <kanji>store</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: That's the natural next progression of claiming some land. Building a roof upon it and building some shops and stores inside. You'll see why in a moment.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>roof</kanji> covering the dirt is there so that the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (<ja>や</ja>) can play baseball year round. The <kanji>store</kanji>s and <kanji>shop</kanji>s are there to sell hot dogs and Yankees memorabilia.
data.reading_hint: You have yourself a whole Yankees stadium, and all it took was a roof and some shops / stores! If you build it, they will come.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>yurt</radical>'s <radical>stool</radical> is always placed at certain <kanji>degrees</kanji>. The degrees change depending on specific <kanji>occurrence</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Since a yurt is round, the stool has to be angled at certain degrees. It's part of yurt culture. Imagine someone adjusting the stool with a measurement tool to adjust it to an exact degree.
data.reading_mnemonic: Also angled at exact <kanji>degrees</kanji> is the <reading>do</reading>g (<ja>ど</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The dog changes its degrees at every occurrence of the stool changing. Picture the dog leaning at the exact degree the stool is at.

data.meaning_mnemonic: People who <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>temple</radical> are probably just trying to <kanji>wait</kanji>. They don't mean to look like they're up to no good, but it's hard to wait without looking suspicious when you're waiting outside a temple.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine waiting outside a temple. People are giving you looks. People think you're loitering, not just waiting innocently.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>wait</kanji> outside the temple, you can't help but adjust your <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). When you wait you get nervous, and when you get nervous you fidget. So now you're messing with your tie a whole bunch.
data.reading_hint: Imagine adjusting your tie as you wait. Oh no, now even more people are staring at you. The tie thing is making you look even more suspicious!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to get your <radical>fingers</radical> around a <radical>temple</radical> if you want to <kanji>hold</kanji> it. Is the temple too big? Hold smaller temples you can buy in the temple's souvenir shop.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine holding a tiny temple in your fingers. Hold it up to the light. Hold it on the train. Hold it while you sleep.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>hold</kanji> the temple you hear a voice. You look down through your fingers and see a tiny <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>). He's smiling and gives you a thumbs up. Aww, thanks Jesus!
data.reading_hint: Jesus likes when you hold things like temples. He probably likes when you hold other things too, like ice cream, puppies, and homeless peoples' hands.

data.meaning_mnemonic: All the <radical>rice paddies</radical> are <radical>jammed in</radical>to the <kanji>world</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The world is basically just a bunch of rice paddies smooshed together, if you think about it.
data.reading_mnemonic: To get around this <kanji>world</kanji> of rice paddies, you need to use a <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: A rice paddy is mostly made up of water, just like our world, and you don't want to have wet feet. Use the power of your kayak to become a world traveler.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Once you remove the <radical>lantern</radical> from the <radical>tent</radical>, we will be ready for <kanji>departure</kanji>. We can’t leave the lantern inside of the tent; that’s a fire hazard. We’d best take it with us before the departure. Don’t you agree?
data.meaning_hint: Feel the heat from the lantern. It’s not quite as comforting as being inside a tent, but it’s better than nothing. The lantern will light your way on your departure.
data.reading_mnemonic: Oh! Don’t forget your <reading>hats</reading> (<ja>はつ</ja>) either. Wouldn’t want to start a <kanji>departure</kanji> without hats or a lantern. That’d be a short journey.
data.reading_hint: How cold and unprotected would your head be without a hat? Very. Taking hats along with departures is integral to their success. Imagine how unsafe you would feel with no hats. That’s no departure I want to set out on.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You need to look a <radical>tree</radical> in the <radical>eye</radical> to gain a <kanji>mutual</kanji> respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.
data.meaning_hint: It's the same with humans, you know? If you want to have a mutual relationship you need to be able to look each other in the eyes. If you're too embarrassed, or you look down on them, then that isn't mutual respect!
data.reading_mnemonic: If your respect for the tree is <kanji>mutual</kanji> with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding."
data.reading_hint: This is basically a FernGully moment, you know? You can feel the tree's pain like it's your pain. It's that kind of mutual sharing of souls you need.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> of a <radical>small</radical> <radical>lion</radical> gazes upon the <kanji>prefecture</kanji> that will one day become his. He’s a small lion prince, but once he grows up, everything reflected in his eye will be his prefecture to rule over.
data.meaning_hint: You remember the old classic movie about the white lion and his prefecture. No? Oh, you're thinking of that big studio knock off. That's okay, whatever makes you remember the laws of prefectural rule.
data.reading_mnemonic: This small lion's <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is being protected by <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai because the lion is too small to protect all of this land himself. Ken the samurai is used to wandering far and wide, so one, eye-sized prefecture is nothing to him.
data.reading_hint: Picture Ken protecting the prefecture, punching hyenas in the face, and yelling, "This may just be a prefecture, not a country, but I'll give it my all for my lion king!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: A beast <radical>king</radical> with <radical>big</radical> <radical>horns</radical> marries a true <kanji>beauty</kanji>. The big horned king may look like a beast, but the beauty loves him for what’s inside. That is where true beauty lies.
data.meaning_hint: I’m sure you know of Beauty and the Beast. Remember that movie? Think of the king and his big horns. And remember the beauty that loved him.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Beauty</kanji> and the who? Beauty and the <reading>Bea</reading>st (<ja>び</ja>). The Beast. That’s right. Beauty and the Beast! How could you forget?
data.reading_hint: It’s a Disney movie. Everyone knows about it. How many times have you seen it? Remember the movie Beauty and the Beast.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you're in <radical>prison</radical>, whoever ends up with the <radical>shellfish</radical> will <kanji>lose</kanji>. It's the game all prisoners play. It's like keep away from the shellfish. And if you end up with the shellfish BZZZZTT that's it, you're the loser.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that it's your first day in prison. You're walking around the yard, minding your own business, when suddenly a shellfish smacks you right in the head and falls into your open hands. "HAHA YOU LOSE!" someone shouts.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>lose</kanji>, you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (<ja>ふ</ja>). All you had to do was not hold the prison shellfish. It really shouldn't have been that hard to not lose, ya fool.
data.reading_hint: Now you have to try to make some other fool lose. Otherwise you'll be the loser fool forever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On its <radical>scooter</radical>, a <radical>horn</radical>ed creature from <radical>heaven</radical> will take things you want to <kanji>send</kanji> there.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the horned thing on its scooter, a big messenger bag over its shoulder with the kanji for heaven on it. "You got somethin' you want me to send?" it mutters.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>send</kanji> your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) to heaven. I mean, you don't want it to go to some of those other places you've heard of, so why not send your soul?
data.reading_hint: You put your soul into an envelope, stick a stamp on it, and hand it off to be sent to heaven. Bye bye! I hope this doesn't have any negative effects on your body!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>heavy</radical> radical and the <kanji>heavy</kanji> kanji are the same.
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: In your hand is a very <kanji>heavy</kanji> <reading>jew</reading>el (<ja>じゅう</ja>). Real jewels are always heavier than they look.
data.reading_hint: Imagine holding a real jewel in your right hand and a fake jewel in your left. The one in your right hand is suuuuupeerrr heavy!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> things around a <radical>fire</radical>. In fact there are two <radical>fire</radical>s, and you're <kanji>discuss</kanji>ing something that's really important to you with a group of people, all sitting around two nice campfires.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself next to the two campfires, having a heart-to-heart discussion. What are you saying?
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>discuss</kanji> in this intense, fiery way all the way until <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>), but no longer! Once dawn comes the discussion needs to be concluded.
data.reading_hint: If you try to discuss something all night and past dawn, you'll burn out. Take the day, think, then tonight you can try to discuss it again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who pilots a <radical>helicopter</radical> will have the insatiable <kanji>need</kanji> for something. She doesn't know what it is. But she needs it. And that's why she's flying around looking for it!
data.meaning_hint: Picture the woman in the helicopter needing something. She's looking around. Searching. But she doesn't know what it is!
data.reading_mnemonic: Finally she knows what she <kanji>need</kanji>s! It's <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>)! Delicious, creamy yogurt!
data.reading_hint: What does she need? Yogurt!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> grants a <radical>gladiator</radical> its <radical>power</radical> so he will <kanji>win</kanji>! <kanji>Victory</kanji> will be his!
data.meaning_hint: Watch as the moon's power fills the gladiator. He starts to glow, grows larger, and has some craters on his face now. Well.. okay.
data.reading_mnemonic: He <kanji>win</kanji>s over and over again, and soon the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) is even rooting for him. In fact, the Shougun claims him as his personal gladiator of choice.
data.reading_hint: The Shougun is only interested in people who win. But you probably could have guessed that already.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> is very <radical>anti</radical>-everything, making it all <kanji>temporary</kanji>. You get a new shirt, "I'm anti shirts!" he yells, and out it goes.
data.meaning_hint: He tires of things so quickly, you hardly have time to get used to them before they're gone.
data.reading_mnemonic: The leader's most <kanji>temporary</kanji> possession is his <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). Or... cars, because they're all very temporary. He buys one, drives it around, and then suddenly he's anti red car. He needs a blue one!
data.reading_hint: Picture all of the temporary cars he's tried filling up an entire junkyard. They're all a little different, but in the end they were all just temporary fads.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Run</radical> into <radical>oneself</radical> in a dream and you'll definitely <kanji>wake up</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: If you run into yourself, it really messes you up, you know? You won't be able to handle what you're seeing so you have to wake up.
data.reading_mnemonic: If one runs into oneself and you don't <kanji>wake up</kanji>, just look down at your waist. If you're wearing an <reading>o</reading>bi (<ja>お</ja>) you know it's a dream and you'll eventually wake up. If you aren't wearing an obi then it isn't a dream and you don't have anything to wake up from.
data.reading_hint: Your obi is like a special object you only have in dreams. If you have your obi, it's okay, it's a dream and you can wake up now! Make sure you memorize exactly how it feels so dream-you can't trick you or something.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You jump on your <radical>scooter</radical> with a big <radical>bundle</radical> to go as <kanji>fast</kanji> as you can! You have a bundle of pizzas in here, and they need to be delivered as fast as you can get them there!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how fast you can go on your scooter holding this bundle. It's way faster than trying to go on foot, that's for sure!
data.reading_mnemonic: You were going so <kanji>fast</kanji>, you only put on <reading>sock</reading>s (<ja>そく</ja>). So now you're barreling down the street at top speeds in just your sad, white socks.
data.reading_hint: Imagine riding the scooter as fast as you can in just your socks. You can feel the wind pulling them off your feet!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You don't want to keep all the <radical>alcohol</radical> to yourself (<radical>oneself</radical>), so you <kanji>distribute</kanji> it to all of your friends. Heck, not just your friends, to everyone you can find!
data.meaning_hint: Don't be that person who keeps the alcohol all to themselves. Distribute it to all of the legally-aged people you know!
data.reading_mnemonic:
As you <kanji>distribute</kanji> the alcohol you say a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>):

Here you go my friends
Alcohol for everyone
Never drink alone
data.reading_hint: This becomes the haiku you say before every party, every potluck, and every night out at the bar. You even get it tattoo'd to your arm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is an <radical>alcohol</radical>ic beverage containing a lot of <kanji>alcohol</kanji>. It’s 3 different kinds of rums, pineapple juice, and grenadine. It’ll hit you like a tsunami though. This alcoholic drink has a kick to it.
data.meaning_hint: It’s made with spiced rum, coconut rum, and dark rum. Imagine yourself on a sandy beach drinking this cocktail. Feel the sun on your face and the wind in your hair as you sip on this fruity and rummy alcoholic beverage known as a tsunami. You could even picture an actual tsunami in the water coming right for you. I wouldn’t recommend it though—actual tsunami are scary, not drinkable and delicious.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you lay on this beach, the <kanji>alcohol</kanji> keeps coming down a <reading>chu</reading>te (<ja>しゅ</ja>), straight into your mouth. You can feel the sand in your toes and the alcohol sliding down your throat from this special tsunami chute.
data.reading_hint: Picture the alcohol flowing down this long chute from somewhere far away. You try to see where it's coming from, but all you can see is this long, long chute stretching along the entire beach, until it disappears into the distance. You should probably be concerned that you're nonstop drinking alcohol from a random chute, but it tastes so good!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> has a <radical>roof</radical> and will teach you about the <radical>origin</radical> of many things. It's an <kanji>institution</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Institutions are places of learning, but they have to be a physical place with a roof and all that. If you're learning out in a field somewhere, that's probably not a proper institution.
data.reading_mnemonic: What does <kanji>institution</kanji> start with? In (<ja>いん</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: Just remember, it's an IN-stitution, and you'll know this reading easy-peasy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> splits in <radical>two</radical> when the year comes to an <kanji>end</kanji>. One half symbolizes the year you were just in, and the other symbolizes the new year beginning, cutting winter in half and <kanji>finish</kanji>ing off the year.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the threads that symbolize winter splitting in two to mark the end of the year. Winter isn't finished though, it's only half done.
data.reading_mnemonic: Right as winter <kanji>end</kanji>s you grab the two threads and lace them into your <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>). Oh, you thought these were metaphorical? No they're real threads, although, they're technically shoe laces now.
data.reading_hint: It's the end of the year, so it's time for new shoe laces!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You find some <radical>white</radical> <radical>feathers</radical> and you want to <kanji>learn</kanji> more about where they came from and what they're made of.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself in a library poring through huge tomes on birds, feathers, and the history of white birds. You want to learn everything you can!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>learn</kanji> that you should tie these white feathers to your <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>). You do it before you learn what it will do, and then suddenly you're jump-flying out of the building.
data.reading_hint: Oh geez, oh no. You better learn how to control these shoes before you—CRASH!!! Welp, you just shot through a plane. You need to learn more before you act next time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>car</radical> runs into a <radical>cloud</radical> you'll <kanji>revolve</kanji> around it instead of going straight through. Clouds are really hard to see through, so even though you're trying not to, you revolve in a tight circle up and around the cloud anyway.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine driving your car around and around the cloud, instead of going through it. At least it's soft and cool.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>revolve</kanji> around the cloud <reading>ten</reading> (<ja>てん</ja>) times before it disappears and you're able to go through.
data.reading_hint: Unfortunately, not long after you get through that cloud another one comes down and gets in your way. Now you're counting each revolution, one... two... three... all the way up to ten.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You give your <radical>scooter</radical> to a <radical>turkey</radical> so that it can <kanji>advance</kanji>. The turkey was trying and failing to walk through a crowded street, so out of the goodness of your heart you gave it a scooter so it could advance.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine picking up the turkey and putting it on your scooter. Of course, you give it your helmet as well, safety first.
data.reading_mnemonic: You wave as the turkey <kanji>advance</kanji>s into the street at top speeds, collides with a car, and scrapes up its <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>) almost immediately. Ah!
data.reading_hint: Silly turkey, you can't advance that fast, of course you'll hurt your shins. It's better to advance slowly, but I guess I couldn't expect you to know that.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A violent <radical>tsunami</radical> causes <radical>flowers</radical> to be ripped from the branches of trees and they swirl around and <radical>kiss</radical> your face gently as they <kanji>fall</kanji>. With the tsunami came a great windy storm that blew many flowers all about. It’s a pretty sight amongst all the destruction.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being out in this tsunami induced storm. You can feel the rain and wind on your skin – you’re wet, cold, and scared. But you see some flowers being blown to the ground and you are mesmerized by the dance they do on the wind before they finally fall to the ground.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to save these flowers you see <kanji>fall</kanji>ing in around you, so you take out a drying <reading>rack</reading> (<ja>らく</ja>) and place them carefully on it. Now whenever you feel scared, you can look at the flowers on this rack and you won't be scared anymore.
data.reading_hint: Imagine running around catching the flowers as they fall. Imagine placing each little petal onto the rack to keep it safe and dry.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>world</radical> of <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>tree</radical>s, the most important thing is the <kanji>leaf</kanji>. <kanji>Leaves</kanji> are how flowers and trees get their nutrients from the sun!
data.meaning_hint: Leaves, no matter how little, are the most important thing in the world for them.
data.reading_mnemonic: Picture a little flower working really hard to grow its first leaf. The <kanji>leaf</kanji> pops out and it shouts, "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)!"
data.reading_hint: <ja>は</ja> is the sound of a leaf coming into existence. Whenever you see a plant from now on, hear the little ha sound it makes when each leaf pops out of its body.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tombstone</radical> may be heavy for a human, but to a <radical>car</radical>, they’re relatively <kanji>lightweight</kanji>. Cars are very strong, you see, so something heavy like a tombstone is no match for them. All cars find tombstones to be lightweight and easy to transport.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself trying to move a huge slab tombstone. It’s difficult, no? I bet you wish you had a car or some other vehicle to make the process much less painful. Your arms are getting sore from carrying the tombstone and you’re getting sweaty and hot from all the work. What you would do for a car with air conditioning.
data.reading_mnemonic: What do you wish you had to transport this tombstone? Oh, that’s right – a <reading>car</reading> (<ja>かる</ja>). If you had a car, this tombstone moving business would be no problem. To cars, tombstones are naught but <kanji>lightweight</kanji> pebbles!
data.reading_hint: Remember all that hard work you were doing before and how you got all sweaty and gross? Now imagine yourself inside of a nice car with air conditioning, and the tombstone in the trunk. It feels great doesn’t it? The air conditioning is perfect, and driving a car is much easier than carrying a tombstone around.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you ride your <radical>scooter</radical>, your <radical>forehead</radical> sticks out of the <radical>car</radical>, so you have to <kanji>carry</kanji> it. The scooter doesn't fit in the car when you aren't on it though, so you have to carry it out the window. And it takes a lot of <kanji>luck</kanji> not to get clipped by a car or accidentally take out a pedestrian with it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to carry your scooter out the window. Your forehead is still sticking out of the car as you do this.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>carry</kanji> the scooter, your <kanji>luck</kanji> turns, and it starts to rain, so you pull out your <reading>um</reading>brella (<ja>うん</ja>). Now you're holding your scooter, your forehead, and an umbrella outside of the car.
data.reading_hint: It's hard enough to carry a scooter while you drive, but now you have to try to keep yourself and it dry with an umbrella too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gate</radical> with a <radical>lantern</radical> is <kanji>open</kanji> for you. That's convenient, since it's pretty dark out and you might not have seen the open gate without the lantern's help.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being a traveler, walking around the outside of a huge walled city. You really need to get inside but all of the gates are closed. Finally, you see a single, bright lantern marking the open gate! What a relief.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>open</kanji> gate is in the water though, so you'll need a <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>) to get in. Luckily, you've been carrying your kayak with you just in case.
data.reading_hint: Imagine kayaking in the dark toward an open gate. Finally, you've made it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You chase a <radical>turkey</radical> up a <radical>tree</radical> to <kanji>collect</kanji> it. At least, you will once you've <kanji>gather</kanji>ed enough turkeys into this one tree.
data.meaning_hint: Collect another turkey, send it flying and gobbling up into the tree next to the other one.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you've <kanji>collect</kanji>ed enough turkeys, you're going to turn them into a <reading>shoe</reading> (<ja>しゅう</ja>). Maybe even two shoes, but that will mean <kanji>gather</kanji>ing even more turkeys!
data.reading_hint: Picture the nice, feathered shoes you'll be able to make once you've gathered all of these turkeys together. Ohoho, you can't wait! Go collect another turkey!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You can <radical>eat</radical> all you want, but you'll still <radical>lack</radical> something to <kanji>drink</kanji>. You can't live just from eating, you have to drink things too!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine eating and eating and lacking a delicious, cold, thirst-quenching drink. Your mouth is dry. You have to drink something, anything!
data.reading_mnemonic: You get desperate for a <kanji>drink</kanji> and put some <reading>no</reading>ri (<ja>の</ja>) seaweed in a blender, trying to create a drink of your own.
data.reading_hint: Luckily, this nori isn't dried and pressed like they usually are, and you manage to make a bright green nori drink. You gulp it down, and even though it tastes like the ocean, it hits the spot!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>sheep</radical> is having trouble trying to eat a fish with <radical>spikes</radical> on its <radical>fins</radical>, then the sheep probably has no <kanji>business</kanji> trying to eat it in the first place. Don’t sheep usually eat like, grass and stuff? What is this sheep doing trying to eat a fish with spikes on its fins? What silly business this is.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this crazy sheep. Why is it trying to eat this fish? This sheep is blood crazed. Blood crazed for fish meat, especially the meat from fish with spikes on their fins. This crazed sheep means business.
data.reading_mnemonic: What’s this? The sheep is also trying to eat some <reading>gyo</reading>za (<ja>ぎょう</ja>) dumplings! Where will this sheep’s madness end? First spikey finned fish and now gyoza? This is some crazy <kanji>business</kanji>.
data.reading_hint: Imagine you’re at an Asian style restaurant and you just ordered a big plate of gyoza dumplings. Next thing you know, this crazy sheep busts through the front door and starts devouring all your gyoza! Where did this sheep come from and why does he love gyoza so much!?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hit ancient <radical>China</radical> and formed the <kanji>Chinese</kanji> country we know now as... <kanji>China</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Picture the world way far away, from space. You see a giant tsunami carve out a massive chunk of land to the west of Japan on the main continent. Slowly the tsunami waters recede, leaving the outline of China.
data.reading_mnemonic: You peer closer at <kanji>China</kanji> and realize the borders are inching inward, even though the tsunami is already gone. You look even closer and see the Mongols, being led by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>) moving in to conquer all of the Chinese people living in China!
data.reading_hint: Watch as the Khan takes China for himself. A tiny little flag with a horse on it is raised in the middle, for all of the Chinese people to see. Hmm, this could be a problem.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you’ve been walking all day, nobody is going to want to <radical>kiss</radical> your <radical>foot</radical> if you’ve been walking barefoot down a dirt <kanji>road</kanji>. Your feet are filthy, sweaty, and stinky. Nobody is going to want to kiss those feet.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine kissing someone’s foot. Now imagine kissing someone’s foot after they’ve been walking down a dirt road for hours. It’s disgusting. Smell the stench of dirt and sweat wafting up into your nostrils as the foot approaches your lips. It’s wretched.
data.reading_mnemonic: What was this person walking down again? Oh, that’s right – a <reading>ro</reading>ad (<ja>ろ</ja>). They were walking down a dirt <kanji>road</kanji>.
data.reading_hint: Walking down a dirt road barefoot like this is a sure way to dirty up your feet. Feel the dirt, rocks, and twigs under your feet. The road is hard and dry and is not making your journey very comfortable at all.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You blast your <radical>music</radical> loud so it causes a <radical>landslide</radical>, revealing the perfect soil for <kanji>farming</kanji>! Musically moved dirt is perfect for <kanji>agriculture</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine slowly turning up your big boombox until your ears hurt and the ground beneath your feet is vibrating with the beat. Soon you and the boombox are sliding with all of the earth down the hill and onto your farmland. Hooray, now the farming can begin!
data.reading_mnemonic: The first person to come up with this <kanji>farming</kanji> method was <reading>No</reading>stradamus (<ja>のう</ja>), the famous seer and prophecy man. He predicted humans of the future would use special "yell cubes" to "move that good earth."
data.reading_hint: Picture Nostradamus flailing his arms and trying to explain his vision to the farmers at the time. He knows that if they listen their farming techniques will improve, but they're looking at him like he's nuts.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You look at some <radical>gold</radical> and notice a <radical>fault</radical> in it. You scrape at the fault and see that it's just sprayed with gold paint. It's not gold, it's (comparatively) worthless <kanji>iron</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: You think you've found a ton of gold bars! Imagine being so happy about this. Then, imagine your heart dropping in your chest when you notice the fault. Then, it dropping down even farther when you figure out it's merely iron.
data.reading_mnemonic: Do you know that movie, <reading>Tetsu</reading>o (<ja>てつ</ja>) the <kanji>Iron</kanji> Man? We talked about it on Tofugu a while back. It’s one of the wackiest Japanese movies of all time. If you don’t know about Tetsuo the Iron Man, you should definitely look it up (if you aren't averse to horror/violent films). Tetsuo is one of the most insane movies in the history of ever.
data.reading_hint: Watch a trailer on YouTube for Tetsuo the Iron Man. Go ahead, do it now – I’ll wait. Did you watch it? Remember that nonsense every time you see this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>lack</radical> a <radical>lip ring</radical> (or two in this case) it's going to make it way easier for you to sing a <kanji>song</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a song with lip rings. Then imagine one without. Sing them, pretending you have lip rings. It doesn't work as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're singing a <kanji>song</kanji> with all these lip rings in your mouth and you sound terrible. You're on the side of the road singing. People are freaking out. Finally, someone drives into you with their <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself getting hit by this car. All the air flies out of you as you sing your <kanji>song</kanji>. You think "I shouldn't have tried to sing a song with all these lip rings..."

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you get stabbed in the <radical>eye</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> times with <radical>bamboo</radical>, you’re going to have a hard time beginning to <kanji>calculate</kanji> where anything is. Taking a bamboo shoot to the eye is no pleasant experience, especially if done twenty times. You’d be blinded for sure. And a newly blinded person is going to have one heck of a time calculating where everything is without the power of sight.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine getting jabbed with a bamboo shoot. Now imagine getting jabbed in the eye with a bamboo shoot. It’s going to hurt. Try and calculate exactly how painful this would be and imagine it happening to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Do you know how <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>) punishes naughty boys and girls in Asia? He doesn’t give them coal, Santa-san tortures them with twenty bamboo jabs to the eye. Yikes. Do you know how Santa-san <kanji>calculate</kanji>s who is naughty and who is nice? By their school grades, of course.
data.reading_hint: Picture this evil Asian Santa-san, clad in blood red garments and brandishing pointed bamboo shoots in each hand. He’s a cold and calculating madman! You’d better start studying! Santa-san is watching!

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you press your <radical>ear</radical> up to a <radical>gate</radical>, you’re likely to <kanji>hear</kanji> what’s going on on the other side. The other people on the other side won’t know you are listening to their conversation because you are so sneaky and clever. They’ve no idea you’re on the other side of the gate hearing every word they say.
data.meaning_hint: I’m sure you’ve pressed your ear up against a wall, door, or gate at sometime to hear what’s going on on the other side of it. Remember back to a time you did this and how sneaky you felt listening in on people without them knowing. You sneaky frood, you.
data.reading_mnemonic: From the other side of the gate, you <kanji>hear</kanji> one of the people on the other side start to play a song on a recorder. You recognize the song as “Hot Cross <reading>Bun</reading>s (<ja>ぶん</ja>).” You haven’t heard this song in a long time. “Hot cross buns… hot cross buns~”
data.reading_hint: I’m sure many of you were forced to play the recorder in school at some point and were made to play the song known as hot cross buns. Picture yourself playing this song and remember the melody when you see this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> between <radical>five</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s is a <kanji>language</kanji>. As long as there are five different people saying these same words with their five mouths, it's considered its own language.
data.meaning_hint: Picture these five mouths saying the same language to each other. They can understand each other! The mouths are smiling and laughing too.
data.reading_mnemonic: Another mouth joins in speaking the <kanji>language</kanji>, but it's green and scaled and... it's <reading>Go</reading>dzilla's (<ja>ご</ja>) mouth! Godzilla speaks this language too.
data.reading_hint: Godzilla speaks a language some people understand! You wish you knew this earlier, then you might have been able to stop some of his destruction. Try to say, "Hey Godzilla, please stop destroying my city," in his language. It's a lot of growling and yelling. He doesn't seem to understand you. You better practice your pronunciation.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>say</radical> what you’re <radical>sell</radical>ing because people don’t like to <kanji>read</kanji>. If they walk right by and don’t read, you better say what you have for sale so they’ll know! Read it out loud to them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine reading what you have for sale out loud to people walking by because they’re too lazy to read it for themselves.
data.reading_mnemonic: What are you forced to <kanji>read</kanji> aloud to sell? <reading>Yo-</reading>yo (<ja>よ</ja>) instructions! You’d think they’d be self explanatory, but there are actually a lot of rules and tricks that you have to read to get good at yo-yoing. Read all of these out loud so you can sell them.
data.reading_hint: Imagine reading through your list of yo-yo tricks. Do you know how to pronounce those weird yo-yo names?

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>bird</radical> opens its <radical>mouth</radical>, you’re most likely to hear a <kanji>chirp</kanji>. This is how birds communicate. They open their mouths and let out a series of chirps. Chirp chirp chirp!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself out in the wilderness on a sunny spring day. The weather is perfect and the scenery is beautiful. The only sound you can hear is the chirp of birds throughout the woods around you. It’s very peaceful.
data.reading_mnemonic: The best place to experience the <kanji>chirp</kanji> chirping of birds is when you’re out in <reading>na</reading>ture (<ja>な</ja>). You’re not going to hear birds chirping in a crowded city, so you need to get out into nature to fully experience the birds and their chirps.
data.reading_hint: Nature is a great place to clear your mind and relax. Picture yourself in nature’s wilderness once again. The sun on your face, the wind in your hair, the grass beneath your feet, and the chirps of birds in the air. It’s quite nice.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If someone falls overboard while you're <radical>white</radical> <radical>water </radical>rafting, you can use a long piece of <radical>thread</radical> as a life <kanji>line</kanji>. Sure it might be thin, but a line of thread is better than nothing. Throw them a line and drag them back aboard! Those white water rapids are vicious.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine you're the person who fell overboard. The white water is rushing violently and it is deathly cold. Feel the water and freezing temperature on your skin. But look! Someone has thrown you a line of thread! You're saved!
data.reading_mnemonic: The person who threw you that <kanji>line</kanji> of thread is actually a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>). How kind of him. After you are safe you hop on the centaur's back and ride around to get the wind to dry you off.
data.reading_hint: Coming out of the rushing water, this centaur is like an angel sent from heaven. He's just saved your life. Imagine the happiness and gratitude you feel towards this centaur as you are pulled to safety by that line of thread.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> marked with a <radical>yellow</radical> X on the <kanji>side</kanji> of the house is going to get cut down. You’ve marked it with a yellow X so the hired help knows which tree to cut down. There are a lot of trees on the side of the house, but the tree marked with a yellow X is the only one in danger of causing damage to your roof in the event of a storm.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the scene of a woman with a chainsaw cutting down this tree marked with a yellow X. Hear the sound of the chainsaw buzzing and the grinding of wood as it meets the side of the trunk. It’s very loud. Woodchips go flying everywhere.
data.reading_mnemonic: Wait, that woman with the chainsaw is <reading>Yoko</reading> (<ja>よこ</ja>) Ono! Yes, the same Yoko Ono who’s married to John Lennon of the Beatles. What’s she doing chopping down trees on the <kanji>side</kanji> of your house? Who can say. Silly Yoko.
data.reading_hint: Now picture the same scene as before only imagining Yoko Ono wielding that chainsaw. Maybe she’s dancing. Maybe there’s some Beatles music playing in the background. Either way it’s a strange sight – remember it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> something about the <radical>circumference</radical> of this area. You've looked around this whole area, making a big circle around it, because you are trying to <kanji>investigate</kanji> something that happened here. You also say this thing in a really quiet <kanji>tone</kanji> of voice, because you don't want the person or thing you're investigating to know you're on to them.
data.meaning_hint: Because the radical <radical>circumference</radical> is in play, you can think of the crime scene you're investigating as a statue of a giant globe, and you're doing a circumference around it. Then, in the reading, we'll think about what you'll <radical>say</radical>.
data.reading_mnemonic: "I came here to <kanji>investigate</kanji> this place, and I did indeed find out who the criminal is... it's none other than Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>)!"
data.reading_hint: From what you know about evil Mrs. Chou, you probably could have guessed it was her. The "Circumference Investigation" is now over, though you do still have to catch the perp, Mrs. Chou.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>see</radical> a <radical>tree</radical> that you want to <radical>stand</radical> under to take a break while hiking, a good <kanji>parent</kanji> will stand under the tree with you. This is a kind and caring parent who can see that you are tired and want to relax by standing in the shade of this tree.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that you’re on a long mountain hike and so far you’ve been hiking all in the sun with no shade. Feel the sun beating down on your back, the sweat getting in your eyes. Finally you see a tree to seek refuge under. It’s like an oasis in a desert. You’re saved!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you get closer to the tree, you and your <kanji>parent</kanji> see that it has some pretty crazy roots coming out of it. While making your way into the shade, you manage to bang your <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>) on one of these roots. Your shins already hurt from walking so much, and this is just icing on the cake.
data.reading_hint: Busting your shins on things really hurts. I'm sure you've hit your shins on coffee tables and the like all your life. Remember that pain and think how much worse it would be banging your bare shins on pointy tree roots after you've been hiking all day in the hot sun. Not enjoyable.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>geoduck</radical> eats lots of <radical>beans</radical>, its <kanji>head</kanji> will grow larger. To a geoduck, beans are a brain food, so by eating beans, a geoduck’s head will grow incredibly large. Geoducks already look strange enough as it is, let alone with engorged heads.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine, if you will, a geoduck. Now imagine that same geoduck with a massive head. It looks ridiculous, and more disgusting than ever. It’s actually really creeping you out, because the head keeps getting larger as the geoduck eats more beans. Ew.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the geoduck eats more and more beans, its <kanji>head</kanji> gets bigger and bigger until finally the geoduck’s head explodes like an <reading>atomi</reading>c (<ja>あたま</ja>) bomb. BOOM! Geoduck parts go flying everywhere and pieces of the geoduck’s massive head float to the ground as atomic fallout.
data.reading_hint: Remember how gross geoducks are? Of course you do. Now imagine one exploding right in front of you. You’ve got geoduck mess all over yourself. It’s gross, slimy, sticky, and covering you from head to toe. It’s wretched.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Here you <radical>stand</radical>, a <radical>hair</radical>’s breadth away from the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical>, when out of nowhere a <radical>geoduck</radical> slaps you right in the <kanji>face</kanji>. Geoducks are gross, and you back away from the edge of the cliff you were standing but a hair’s breadth away from just before. Your face is all gooey from the geoduck’s slimy residue.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being slapped in the face with a geoduck. It’s probably one of the worst things that could ever happen to someone. Those things are disgusting. Now you have geoduck goo all over your face. It’s sticky and slimy and gross.
data.reading_mnemonic: But where did that geoduck come from anyway? As you turn around from the cliff edge, wiping the goop from your <kanji>face</kanji> and out of your eyes, you see an angry <reading>cow</reading> (<ja>かお</ja>). This cow is the one who hit you in the face with this geoduck. I know not the reason, but this cow is most definitely not happy with you.
data.reading_hint: Cows are big animals. So you probably got hit in the face with that geoduck pretty hard. Feel the geoduck shaped welt starting to form on the side of your face. It’s very painful and stings a lot.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sick</radical> stick of <radical>dynamite</radical> is going to be <kanji>sick</kanji> forever. Unfortunately there are no medicines that are effective on sticks of dynamite, so once they contract a sickness, they’re sick for good.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if you were a sick stick of dynamite. Every time you sneezed you ran the risk of blowing up. It would be a terrifying way to live. Just imagine it.
data.reading_mnemonic: Being nervous all the time about spontaneously exploding would probably make you sweat profusely. And you know what sweating causes? <reading>B.O.</reading> (<ja>びょう</ja>). You’d be one smelly stick of dynamite. B.O. is a very unpleasant smell, and being <kanji>sick</kanji> is no excuse.
data.reading_hint: Picture this as your life. You could explode at any moment, you’re sick, and you have B.O. Nobody wants to be around you because you might explode and kill them, and you stink. What a terrible way to live!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Let the <radical>sun</radical> shine into your <radical>ear</radical> while sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and make sure <kanji>most</kanji> of it gets in your head. You want to fill your brain with the most sun anyone has ever.
data.meaning_hint: Most of the sun is getting into your ear, but not all of it. Darn, maybe you should try angling yourself a different way.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Most</kanji> of this is for your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>). You're testing out a new way to power it, but if you can't get most of the sun into your ear, it won't be enough to power most of the cyborg's robo-parts.
data.reading_hint: Install the part into your cyborg. As long as most of the sun gets into its human ear, most of its cyborg bits will have power.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you keep a <radical>wolverine</radical> in a <radical>prison</radical> with <radical>barb</radical>s, you’re likely to get into a <kanji>conflict</kanji> with animal rights groups. Wolverines aren’t meant to be kept in cages, let alone barbed prisons. There’s going to be some sort of conflict here, and animal activist groups are not going to be happy with you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine you’re the wolverine in this barbed prison. There’s hardly enough room for you to even turn around in here. The barbs keep poking you as well. Have you ever run into a barbed wire fence? It’s not pleasant.
data.reading_mnemonic: When the wolverine cuts itself inside the barbed prison (which is inevitable), the conflict changes. Now there is a <kanji>conflict</kanji> between the wolverine and its <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). Does it lose it and become a shell of its former self? Or does it keep fighting and try to hang onto what's left of its soul?
data.reading_hint: Pretend you're the wolverine once again. You're already in pain from gouging yourself in this barbed prison. But now you can feel a conflict within yourself. Your soul can't take this. You have to hold on, but it's so hard to keep fighting.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>middle</radical> of the road <radical>leader</radical> is likely to have an average <kanji>relationship</kanji> with everyone. He doesn’t really take sides in matters, and just stays in the middle. This makes him seem like sort of a wishy washy people pleaser, and as such his relationships with people are rarely anything more than average.
data.meaning_hint: I’m sure you’ve heard of “flip-floppers” in politics, or people who try and take both sides of an issue, always staying in the middle ground and never really taking a stand. Imagine one of these people to represent this kanji.
data.reading_mnemonic: This kanji is pronounced exactly like the kanji 中 (<ja>なか</ja>). It's one of those kanji where you can figure out the reading from one of the radicals.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your favorite flip-flopper from before. Now imagine that there’s a knocker on his forehead and you get to knock that knocker as hard as you like. Sounds like fun, doesn’t it? Imagine yourself doing this.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>cloud</radical> that he uses to <kanji>transmit</kanji> all of the messages he needs to send to his people. The cloud floats above him and when he wants to tell people something he just whispers into the cloud and it transmits his message really, really loudly to all of them.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this special cloud floating above your leader. It's probably just a speaker attached to a drone covered in cotton balls.
data.reading_mnemonic: As the leader <kanji>transmit</kanji>s his latest series of messages to you and the others, you notice a pretty large <reading>den</reading>t (<ja>でん</ja>) in it. That dent is probably a clue to what this cloud is really made of.
data.reading_hint: You highly doubt this is a magical cloud that can transmit messages. You inch closer to the big dent and try to poke it. Your finger goes right in! Hmm, you're still pretty sure there's a trick to this thing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The card game fish are best at is <radical>blackjack</radical> because they can easily hold the cards with their <radical>fins</radical> <kanji>together</kanji>. In blackjack you don't have to have a huge hand, full of cards. It's just a few, so fish fins can keep them together and just hit or stay.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a fish trying to hold a full hand of cards together. Impossible! Fish don’t have fingers to keep them spread properly. Now imagine a fish trying to hold two cards together and nodding to hit. It's much easier to keep things together this way!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once a year trillions of fish get <kanji>together</kanji> in <reading><ja>きょう</ja></reading><ja>と</ja> to play blackjack. They have a huge tournament there once a year.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a bunch of fish gathering together in <ja>きょうと</ja> to participate in this blackjack tournament. With so many fish all together in one place, it probably smells pretty fishy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>woman</radical> and a <radical>child</radical> in front of you. You <kanji>like</kanji> them very much.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a woman and a child you like very much. Just appreciate them, and think about how much you like those two. The reading mnemonic definitely won't ruin your image of them or anything.
data.reading_mnemonic: "I <kanji>like</kanji> you two," you say to the woman and child. They both turn their heads 180 degrees back towards you. They both have faces that look just like <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>'s. "We like you too," they say in unison.
data.reading_hint: And you DO like them. You have always been a fan of <ja>こういち</ja>'s kanji learning methods, and you feel so lucky to have married a woman who looks just like <ja>こういち</ja> and then (this is the real miracle!) gave birth to a child that looks like <ja>こういち</ja> too. Hashtag blessed.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>drunkard</radical> holds a <radical>sword</radical> it <kanji>becomes</kanji> something else. The drunkard doesn't become a swordsman, they're still just a drunkard. But the sword in their hands does.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the drunkard standing in front of you. He picked up the sword and is holding it above his head. It's becoming... becoming...
data.reading_mnemonic: The sword has <kanji>become</kanji> a <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>)! It's just like the saber you have! Hey, wait.
data.reading_hint:
If a sword becomes a saber in the hands of a drunkard... then what are you? Geez this became pretty deep.

You slice down the drunkard with your saber and become a little more depressed than you were before.

data.meaning_mnemonic: By the time you finish digging a <radical>coffin</radical> hole with nothing but a <radical>spoon</radical>, you’ll be an old <kanji>elderly</kanji> person. Digging with nothing but a spoon takes a long time, especially when the hole needs to be big enough for a coffin. You might as well be digging it for yourself at this rate. By the time you finish, you’ll be all wrinkled and elderly and just about ready to keel over.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself digging a coffin hole with nothing but a spoon. Your hands get all cramped, your wrist starts to hurt, and you get painful blisters on your hands. It takes forever to dig a hole big enough for a coffin!
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that you’re <kanji>elderly</kanji> (and probably about to die) you suddenly crave some delicious <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>). Salmon roe, sea urchin roe, tofugu roe, doesn’t matter. Your old, tired bones need roe after all that hard work!
data.reading_hint: You hated roe when you were still young, but now that you’re an elderly old fart you really want to eat it. Roe is for old people, you guess, as you slurp it up.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s at the highest <kanji>rank</kanji> in an organization. The leader is of the highest rank and stands above all others.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this great leader. Imagine him actually standing on the shoulders of his supporters who are a lower rank than he is. He’s standing atop this great pyramid as a fearless leader.
data.reading_mnemonic: This great leader is actually the leader of the boy scouts. And as we all know, the highest <kanji>rank</kanji> in boy scouts is the rank of <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) scout. This great leader has attained the rank of eagle scout and stands above all other scouts.
data.reading_hint: Picture the same ranking pyramid from before, only all the members are boy scouts, and the leader at the top is an eagle. Hear the piercing screech of the eagle with your ears.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your <radical>clan</radical> wants to live close to the <radical>ground</radical> so he demands you get <kanji>low</kanji>. Low, low, with your belly to the ground. That way you're always below him, since he's the leader.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself, face smooshed into the ground, and you can hear the leader shouting above you, "GET LOW!"
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Low</kanji> people like you can only eat low food like potatoes. But that's boring, so you low people learned to make <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots. You roll them to each other and eat them without lifting your heads.
data.reading_hint: Get low to the ground right now and ask your mom or dad to roll some tater tots towards your face. Eat them up, mm mm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you want a <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>sword</radical>, you have to be the <kanji>first</kanji> one to find it. Do you really think the first person to come across a spirit sword wouldn't want it?! No. So if you're any place but first, you're not getting anything.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine it like commenting on Youtube or Facebook. If you can say FIRST, first, well congrats. You win the internet spirit sword.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you were lucky enough to be the <kanji>first</kanji> one to find the spirit sword, you should open up a small <reading>show</reading> (<ja>しょ</ja>) to show it off! And then you can make yourself the first in line every day to see the show.
data.reading_hint: This is the first show of this type, anywhere in the world!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>mouth</radical> you put a <radical>sword</radical> and a <radical>knife</radical>. Now that you have them in there, you have to make them <kanji>separate</kanji> from each other.
data.meaning_hint: Anyone can put a sword and knife in their mouth. But not everyone can make them separate while still in your mouth.
data.reading_mnemonic: Why are you trying to make a sword and knife <kanji>separate</kanji> in your mouth? Because someone <reading>bets you</reading> (<ja>べつ</ja>) can't do it.
data.reading_hint: "I bet you can't separate the sword and knife," they say in an annoying voice. Alright, time for you to show them. Nobody bets you anything without you blindly trying to do it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Cut <radical>grain</radical>s with a <radical>knife</radical> to make them smaller and you'll make a great <kanji>profit</kanji>. By cutting them, now you can get three grains worth of money for what was once a single grain.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine buying some rice. Now cut all the grains with a knife into smaller grains. Now sell them for two, three, four times the profit!
data.reading_mnemonic: To make an even better <kanji>profit</kanji>, you decide to cut up <reading>ree</reading>ds (<ja>り</ja>) too. You stuff the grains in the reeds and sell that as "self-cooking" sets.
data.reading_hint: Picture all of your reeds full of grains in a row. The entire world will benefit from your crafty invention. And you'll turn a great profit too, which certainly doesn't hurt.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> of <radical>power</radical> sits on a <radical>stool</radical> while her servants <kanji>toil</kanji> away in the kitchen. They are toiling away preparing a feast for this woman of power while she kicks back on her cozy stool. She’s a queen and deserves to be pampered.
data.meaning_hint:
Imagine you are in a position of power and can relax on a stool while your minions toil away in the kitchen to prepare you a feast. It’s good to have money! You’ve got it made. Imagine how smug you feel.

Note - there are a few other kanji that have a similar meaning to this one. This kanji is used in words that refer to doing work, with a focus on making a concerted effort.
data.reading_mnemonic: The servants are making lots of food for you and your <reading>do</reading>g (<ja>ど</ja>). You're really hungry, so you encourage your minions to <kanji>toil</kanji> away faster so that you might feast a bit sooner.
data.reading_hint: Imagine eating all this food with your dog. Hear your dog barking as it woofs up the food next to you as you do the same.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> in a position of <radical>power</radical> does not need to <kanji>labor</kanji> in the fields. Labor is for the weak! A Viking of power takes what he wants, and need not labor for it. A powerful Viking plunders all and takes what he wants!
data.meaning_hint:
Imagine yourself as a powerful Viking. You have the power to take anything you want, pillaging and plundering to your heart’s content. Imagine all the things you would acquire with this sort of power.

Note - there are a few other kanji that have a similar meaning to this one. This kanji is used in words related to physical, or manual labor, with an emphasis on how darn tiring it is!
data.reading_mnemonic: It takes a lot of <kanji>labor</kanji> to harvest <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>) so that’s what the Viking decides to take first! Roe is delicious, but it’s small and delicate. Vikings don’t labor for their own roe! They take it and eat it!
data.reading_hint: Picture this powerful Viking laying siege on a small fishing village and taking all the roe and stuffing it into his bearded face. So much labor went into harvesting that roe! Vikings are so mean!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Orders</radical> coming from your <radical>mouth</radical> will determine the <kanji>fate</kanji> of your men. You are a commanding officer and orders from your mouth are law. Your orders alone determine the ultimate fate of your soldiers.
data.meaning_hint: Pretend you are a high ranking officer and imagine yourself giving orders to your underlings. Imagine all the power and influence you have. It feels good.
data.reading_mnemonic: You are the commanding officer on the <reading>May</reading>flower (<ja>めい</ja>). You give orders to colonize America. The orders spewing from your mouth hole determine the <kanji>fate</kanji> of the settlers and the fate of America and the fate of the world! You and the Mayflower have changed everything forever.
data.reading_hint: Students of American history are very familiar with the Mayflower. Recall learning about it in school whenever you see this kanji. Or look it up on Wikipedia if you don’t know about it. The Mayflower is a big deal!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> on top of the <radical>cliff</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> from the <kanji>coast</kanji> below. Just from looking at the raging <kanji>shore</kanji> below, you'd think everything would be wet, it's splashing everywhere!
data.meaning_hint: You're on top of the mountain and the entire coast is stretching out below. The shore goes as far as your eyes can see.
data.reading_mnemonic: Sitting up there, watching the <kanji>coast</kanji> with you, is <reading>Gan</reading>dhi (<ja>がん</ja>). The world famous Gandhi, is just hanging out up here with you, looking down at what you now realize must be a coast in India.
data.reading_hint: Sit down next to Gandhi and close your eyes. You can hear the water hitting the shore below. The coastal birds are screaming. You crack open an eye and see Gandhi still sitting perfectly still.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When <radical>winter</radical> comes your <radical>direction</radical>, the trees must <kanji>release</kanji> their leaves for the coming cold.
data.meaning_hint: Picture winter heading straight for you and frosting everything over. Now picture the leaves being released by the trees.
data.reading_mnemonic: The trees <kanji>release</kanji> all of their leaves onto your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>). Slowly, you watch in horror as your home is consumed by the released leaves. They enter in through the windows, doors, and the chimney.
data.reading_hint: "Release my home from this leaf prison!" you shout at the now bare trees.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You’ve been playing <radical>blackjack</radical> in the <radical>sun</radical> since <kanji>long ago</kanji>. This is the longest game of blackjack you’ve ever played and it feels like ages since you started. You’ve been sitting out in the sun playing blackjack since long, long ago.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself playing a never-ending game of blackjack out in the hot sun. You’re sticky, sweaty, and tired. But all you can do is continue to play your game of blackjack. It’s miserable.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once you finally finish the game, you walk the long walk back home, in the sun, barefoot, on a dirt road that hasn’t been maintained since <kanji>long ago</kanji>. Your feet are all sweaty from being out in the sun, and walking on this dirt road gives you <reading>muck ashi</reading> (<ja>むかし</ja>). Your ashi (feet) are all mucky and muddy from the combination of dirt and sweat. Your muck ashi are really gross, man.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your muck ashi, all dirty and muddy from walking on that old road from long ago. Feel the muck between the toes of your ashi, squishing with every step. Hear the sound the mud makes as it slides between your sweaty mucky toes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits your <radical>skin</radical> and creates smaller <kanji>wave</kanji>s. Those hit you too!
data.meaning_hint: If you’ve ever been to the ocean or a large lake, you know what kind of forces even small waves can hit with. Now imagine the force with which a tsunami wave would strike you. You’d have the wind knocked out of you for sure.
data.reading_mnemonic: When each <kanji>wave</kanji> hits your body, you shout, "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)!" It's not like it's on purpose. When the wave crashes into you, the wind gets knocked right out of your mouth, making a HA sound.
data.reading_hint: The waves are basically punching you in the gut, forcing the air out of your lungs, and making you shout HA!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>master</radical> has the power to <kanji>pour</kanji> water wherever he pleases. Tsunami masters are masters over the most powerful water force in the universe, so it makes sense that they have the ability to pour water at will, wherever they please. Best not tick off the master, unless you want a tsunami poured on your head.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself as this tsunami master. You’re like a water bender from Avatar, only more awesome. Feel the cold wet water pouring out of your fingertips as you create water out of nothing. Imagine what it would be like to have this power.
data.reading_mnemonic: If <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>) was trying to attack you, you’d be able to defend yourself easily. Simply <kanji>pour</kanji> a tsunami on him and Chewbacca would surrender in a heartbeat. Chewbacca doesn’t like having water poured on him, especially not all the water from a tsunami.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Chewbacca soaking wet. All his fur is matted down and he looks pretty depressed. He smells like wet dog too. Smell this smell in your nostrils as you imagine how pathetic this drenched Chewbacca feels.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Give <radical>trash</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> and it will <kanji>nurture</kanji> and <kanji>raise</kanji> that trash like it's its own little moon baby.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the moon raising this ball of trash, giving it love and attention.
data.reading_mnemonic: The moon <kanji>nurture</kanji>s the trash ball until one day, it speaks! "<reading><ja>行く</ja></reading> (<ja>いく</ja>), <ja>行く！</ja>" it says. It wants to go live with mom moon!
data.reading_hint: Watch as the little trash ball <ja>行く</ja>s up into the sky and floats around its moon mama. If you raise your child right it will want to <ja>行く</ja> wherever you go too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see something that would <radical>suit</radical> you so you use your <radical>fingers</radical> and <kanji>pick up</kanji> the thing you want. You can pick up anything you think suits you. A shiny rock. A new pair of pants. Anything!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine something that would suit your life and your style. Now pick up that thing. Hold it in your fingers. Feel it. It's yours now.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're walking around looking for something to <kanji>pick up</kanji> when you see a sword in a rock. Yes, this will suit you. You pick up the sword and people jump out around you and tell you that you are the new <reading>hero</reading> (<ja>ひろ</ja>)! Uh oh. Maybe you shouldn't have picked this up.
data.reading_hint: You picked up the hero sword and now you're the new hero. Time to go kill a dragon. Good luck, try not to die hero person!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Try to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to <radical>spoon</radical> out some of the <radical>sun</radical> and you'll come back with just one <kanji>finger</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Look down at your finger and the burned stumps where the rest of your fingers used to be. It hurts. And you're sad. But at least you still have one finger left.
data.reading_mnemonic: Don't worry, you aren't the only one out there with just one <kanji>finger</kanji>, <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>) only have one finger too. I mean, they're hooves, which are really just a single animal finger. It's just big and kind of flat.
data.reading_hint: Picture sitting with a sheep. It's right across from you, staring into your eyes. It reaches out its sheep finger hoof and you reach out with your finger. They touch. It's magical.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>sheep</radical> rides a <radical>tsunami</radical> in classic <kanji>Western style</kanji>. And by Western style I mean the sheep is dressed in a cowboy outfit and has put a saddle atop the tsunami wave to ride it. It’s a tsunami rodeo and this crazy sheep is riding that tsunami wave in classic Western style. 

This kanji also means <kanji>ocean</kanji>, because presumably the people from the "West" who have "Western Style" came from across the ocean. They're the "Ocean People" in this sense. You'll want to be familiar with this meaning for vocab later on.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how ridiculous a sheep would look all decked out in Western style cowboy gear. Now imagine it riding a tsunami wave as it screams, “Baa~ baa~ baa~!”
data.reading_mnemonic: After a whole day of riding this tsunami, the sheep is hankerin’ for some <kanji>Western style</kanji> food. This sheep loves <reading>yo</reading>gurt (<ja>よう</ja>). And its favorite flavor is Western style apple pie yogurt. America loves its apple pie and this sheep loves Western style apple pie flavored yogurt.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself eating this Western style apple pie yogurt. It tastes just like apple pie only creamier and fruitier. Taste the sweet yogurt in your mouth as you imagine yourself scarfing some down.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You should have a <radical>spirit</radical> that's <radical>humble</radical> when before a <kanji>god</kanji>. You never really have to act all nice and humble before anyone else, but if you meet a god... well... you should probably lower yourself appropriately. They can smite you and all that.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a spirit appearing before you. It's a god. You should be as humble as possible. Out of respect and also because you don't want to be cursed or something.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you see a <kanji>god</kanji>, you need to get down on your <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>). Get down on your ankles? No, not low enough. Knees? No, no, get your shins flat on the ground to show how humble you really are.
data.reading_hint: If you don't get down on your shins before god, they could take them away. You don't want to live a shin-less life, do you?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You only got a <radical>few</radical> <radical>grain</radical>s on your plate. It only takes you a  <kanji>second</kanji> to eat them. It can't take any longer because there were so few.
data.meaning_hint: Count how many seconds it takes for you to eat the few grains you have. One... oh, they're gone.
data.reading_mnemonic: And also, a <kanji>second</kanji> is how long it takes for your awful <reading>B.O.</reading> (<ja>びょう</ja>) to appear.
data.reading_hint: Whenever you eat a few grains, even if only for a second, you get a terrible reaction seconds later that causes some pretty terrible B.O.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are pieces of <radical>thread</radical> on each <radical>escalator</radical> showing you what <kanji>level</kanji> they go to in your school.
