data.meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets <radical>together</radical> with <radical>water</radical>, only <kanji>violence</kanji> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this violent fight scene in your brain. Imagine water locked in battle with the sun as the sun’s fire flares up and the water starts to sizzle.
data.reading_mnemonic: But after a while, the sun and the water have had enough of <kanji>violence</kanji>. They decide to settle their differences with a friendly game of <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>). Bowling is a great way to relieve stress and in the end, they bond over it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the sun and the water trying to bowl. Hear the sound of bowling balls rolling down the lane and pins rattling around and crashing together.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Compare</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> with a <radical>tsunami</radical> – these two things don’t <kanji>mix</kanji>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the sun getting blocked out as a tsunami rises up from the ocean. Feel the cold fear of death on you as the tsunami approaches. That tsunami is gonna mix you up.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just before the tsunami crashes over you, a <reading>con</reading>dor (<ja>こん</ja>) swoops out of the sky and grabs you up. This condor must be a <kanji>mix</kanji> – a normal condor is not strong enough to pick up a human. The condor must be mixed with something else. Like a pterodactyl.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself getting mixed up in this situation and the pterodactyl sized condor picking you up. Feel the condor’s talons digging into your shoulders as it grabs you up and flies you towards the sun.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you stab somebody in the <radical>tongue</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical>, it’s sure to start a <kanji>riot</kanji>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself getting stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella. It’s very painful. Taste the blood and metal in your mouth as this happens to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just now you realize that the man you stabbed in the tongue with your umbrella was none other than Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy Savage (<ja>らん</ja>). Being a professional wrestler, Macho Man Randy Savage is ready to throw down at a moment’s notice. A <kanji>riot</kanji> immediately erupts. It’s a battle royal with you and Randy at the epicenter.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself squaring off with Macho Man Randy Savage in the middle of this riot. You have the advantage of having an umbrella, but Randy has the advantage of being himself. Picture yourself getting into a fight with him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: “Don’t <radical>loiter</radical> – <radical>run</radical>, <kanji>Junior</kanji>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation involving Nazis and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine Sean Connery saying “Don’t loiter – run, Junior!” and you should have a much easier time remembering this phrase if you remember it in his voice.
data.reading_mnemonic: Deciding not to loiter any longer, Indiana Jones <kanji>Junior</kanji> takes his dad’s advice and starts to run. Unfortunately he wasn’t paying attention to where his feet were and he stubbed his <reading>to</reading>e (<ja>と</ja>) on a jagged rock. His toe is in so much pain that he can’t bear to run any longer and gets overtaken by the Nazis that were chasing them.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as Indiana Jones Junior and this happened to you. Feel the terrible pain of your stubbed toe as Nazis surround you. Hear them jabbering about in German as you clutch your throbbing toe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>sun</radical> <radical>temple</radical>, it's likely you'll <kanji>acquire</kanji> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine loitering around near the sun temple. Maybe you acquire some illegal goods, maybe you just acquire a tan (it is a SUN temple, after all).
data.reading_mnemonic: You managed to <kanji>acquire</kanji> some tobacco, but just as you're about to leave <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu comes marching up to you!! Or at least, his ghost does. He stares you dead in the eyes and says, "I didn't found the shogunate for you to acquire illegal goods and kill your body toking on my soil."
data.reading_hint: Your eyes fill with tears under Tokugawa's gaze and you drop everything you acquired to the ground. You bow before him apologizing. You'll never do this again!

data.meaning_mnemonic: It's important to focus <radical>oneself</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so that one can emerge <kanji>renew</kanji>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine sitting in your house all winter, meditating and thinking about how you can renew yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: Winter ends and, <kanji>renew</kanji>ed, you come out ready to start a new hobby: <reading>ka</reading>yaking (<ja>かい</ja>)! Nothing says renewal like a brand new kayak and sense of purpose in life.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being back in your house in winter. You're thinking about all the kayaking you're gonna do when winter ends. You're even making the movements with your arms, so you'll be a really renewed you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>sell</radical> <radical>thread</radical> if you want to <kanji>continue</kanji> to live. You want to make a living don’t you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine selling thread so you can continue living your life.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>continue</kanji> to sell that thread because a Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (<ja>ぞく</ja>) bike gang is forcing you to do it. You see? If you want to continue to live, you have to appease this Bosozoku gang. You better keep selling!
data.reading_hint: Continue selling thread and paying off the Bosozoku. It’s the only way you can continue to survive!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Both a <radical>scooter</radical> and a <radical>car</radical>. These are both things you'll <kanji>take along</kanji> with you.
data.meaning_hint: You can't decide which one you want, so you take along both.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>take along</kanji> the things you need. Anything else, you can do a <reading>ren</reading>tal (<ja>れん</ja>) for.
data.reading_hint: You remembered your scooter and your car, but you forgot something else! You go to the rental shop and do a rental for that item.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> loses its <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> so it picks them up in his <radical>mouth</radical> to take them to a <kanji>morally good</kanji> doctor who is <kanji>good</kanji> enough to attach them back onto his head. This poor sheep lost his horns and now feels quite sad. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. An evil doctor would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find a morally good doctor to reaffix them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as the good doctor being approached by this forlorn sheep without horns. Hear the clack of the horns together as the sheep drops them out of his mouth onto the ground and lets out a pathetic bleat. “Baa~aa~ah~”
data.reading_mnemonic: Since you are a <kanji>morally good</kanji> doctor, you decide not to murder the sheep and harvest its organs. Instead, as a practitioner of the <kanji>good</kanji> teachings of <reading>Zen</reading> (<ja>ぜん</ja>) Buddhism, you decided to help the sheep out. Your Zen teachings have only increased the power of your healing abilities, so you fix the sheep up in no time.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself using your Zen magic to heal this sheep. Place your hands on the sheep’s horns and imagine returning them to their rightful location on the sheep’s head. Feel the soft wool of the sheep as he bleats in happiness.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put your <radical>mouth</radical> on a <radical>tree</radical> and try to eat it, you’re probably a <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> individual (unless you’re a woodchuck). You don’t need to eat this tree, you have plenty of food at home. Get your mouth off that tree you distressed child.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as this distressed and troubled person. Taste the taste of sap and bark in your mouth as you nom on the tree with all your might.
data.reading_mnemonic: You thought you were the most <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> person in this situation, but then you look up and see a very equally distressed and troubled <reading>con</reading>dor (<ja>こん</ja>). The tree you've been mouthing is its home. And now you've slobbered all over it, ruining this condor's day.
data.reading_hint: Picture a very distressed condor watching you munch your mouth all over its tree house. You've made a condor enemy this day.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>thread</radical> in the middle of a <radical>kiss</radical>, you’re going to <kanji>entangle</kanji> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to kiss someone with a piece of thread between your lips. Feel the thread getting all entangled between the two of you as you lock lips. It’s really detracting from the experience.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is your first kiss ever so getting a thread to <kanji>entangle</kanji> between your lips was really bad <reading>luck</reading> (<ja>らく</ja>). The person you were trying to kiss got really grossed out by the thread and tried to push you away but was so entangled with the thread that they were unable. Bad luck indeed.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself being tied to someone by the tongue with thread. You can’t escape, and you can’t believe your bad luck. Feel the thread tugging on your tongue as you try to get yourself untangled.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>compare</radical> radical and the <kanji>compare</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Compare</kanji> a <reading>he</reading>ro (<ja>ひ</ja>) to a normal person. The hero is obviously more exciting and influential on society. If you compare a hero with a normal person, the hero will always be superior.
data.reading_hint: Try to compare yourself with a hero. What sets them apart from you when you compare them to you? Muscles? Superpowers? Spandex?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flood</radical> and a <radical>fire</radical>! At the same time? This is a <kanji>disaster</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a disaster so bad that there are floods AND fires. That's too much!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>disaster</kanji> was caused by your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>)! It's malfunctioning, running around leaking large amounts of water and breathing fire. I guess you didn't work out all the kinks before you let it roam wild.
data.reading_hint: You better figure out a way to stop your cyborg from causing more disasters like this. Fix it now, or you're gonna be in big trouble.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> is the kind of <radical>person</radical> who would <radical>poop</radical> two times under a <radical>tree</radical> before using a <kanji>machine</kanji> toilet. There’s a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard, squatting down under the tree to poop. You can smell the poop and a faint stench of alcohol in the air. How could he not have realized that there was a portable machine toilet right there?
data.reading_mnemonic: Oh, I see – the door to the outhouse with the machine toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn’t have the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). If he had a <kanji>machine</kanji> like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he’s reduced to pooping under the tree instead.
data.reading_hint: Listen to the drunkard grumbling about the lack of a key as he poops under the tree. He doesn’t sound happy, and every time he stresses to push out the poop, his voice fluctuates. Imagine hearing this in your mind and being a wee bit disgusted.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Sitting on the <radical>lid</radical> of a toilet, an <radical>explosion</radical> of <radical>poop</radical> erupts out, getting feces on your <radical>cross</radical> necklace and a large <kanji>percent</kanji> of your clothing. You were just trying to chill out, sitting on the lid of the toilet, and an explosion of poop just flew out the toilet bowl. Now you have poop all over you, like ninety-nine percent of your body is covered in poop. Even your cross necklace.
data.meaning_hint: This feels disgusting. Imagine yourself being covered in poop. Feel the warm smelly sludge covering your body as the abysmal aroma wafts up into your nostrils. You’re nearly one hundred percent covered in poop.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re emotionally scarred, so you need to eat your comfort food in order to calm yourself down. Your comfort food is <reading>Ritz</reading> (<ja>りつ</ja>) crackers, so you clean one hundred <kanji>percent</kanji> of the poop off you so your body is now zero percent covered by poop, and you start to devour a box of Ritz crackers.
data.reading_hint: Now that the percent of your body covered in poop has reached zero, you can comfortably eat. Imagine yourself eating these Ritz crackers as you slowly start to feel better about life. Taste their buttery crispness as they crumble in your mouth.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fly</radical> radical and the <kanji>fly</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!
data.reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>fly</kanji>, you generate a lot of <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>) because you’re moving so fast through the atmosphere. Normally this heat would be a nuisance, but you’re a superhero so it doesn’t bother you. This is actually the reason you’re able to fly – you’re a superhero and super resistant to heat.
data.reading_hint: You’re flying through the air super fast. Feel the air rushing past you as heat builds up all over your body from rocketing through the air so fast.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You slip off the <radical>roof</radical>, your <radical>life</radical> flashes before your eyes, and you smash your <radical>mouth</radical> on the ground causing some serious <kanji>damage</kanji>. Oof, this is a really bad <kanji>injury</kanji>, you fell all the way off the roof and onto your mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that moment as you fall off the roof. In slow motion you can see the roof moving away, you see yourself as a little kid, a teen, an adult, then BAM you've injured your mouth. Ow ow ow!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you try to assess the <kanji>damage</kanji>, you hear someone shout, "<reading>Guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>), hey, you okay, guy?" They run up to you, but your mouth is too <kanji>damage</kanji>d, you can't respond. "Okay guy, I'm gonna call you Guy now. Let's get you to the hospital."
data.reading_hint: No matter how much you try to wave your hands and gesture, they keep calling you Guy. It's really annoying, actually, because you aren't a guy and you aren't Guy either. But your mouth is too damaged for you to tell him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Regardless of whether or not you wear a <radical>hat</radical> while you <radical>jackhammer</radical>, you’re going to have a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.
data.meaning_hint: The hat you’re wearing is ridiculous, giving you a surplus of bad style. Imagine a bunch of people scowling at you, not only because of your crazy hat, but because of the annoying sound of the jackhammer. Hear the obnoxious noise around you as the jackhammer rattles your bones.
data.reading_mnemonic: One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart <reading>yo</reading>-yo (<ja>よ</ja>) stand. Having a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage.
data.reading_hint: Your hat is doing little to defend you from the onslaught of yo-yos being tossed at you. Feel the yo-yos hitting your body and listen to them roll away after striking you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Chinese</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>difficult</kanji> to find because they are so rare. Chinese turkeys are the rarest variety of turkey, so naturally, finding one is exceedingly difficult.
data.meaning_hint: Try and picture a Chinese turkey in your brain. Now imagine yourself trying to catch it, but you just can’t. It’s too difficult. The Chinese turkey is too elusive.
data.reading_mnemonic: Do you know the actual reason Chinese turkeys are so <kanji>difficult</kanji> to find? Do you know how many Chinese turkeys there are in the world? <reading>None</reading> (<ja>なん</ja>). They don’t exist. How many Chinese turkeys are there? None.
data.reading_hint: So this is why you had such a difficult time finding and catching one – there were none to be caught. Imagine the sadness you felt when you realized that there were no Chinese turkeys to catch and that none exist in this world.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> with <radical>direction</radical> will have things <kanji>obstruct</kanji> her path. It's a sad fact that it's still a man's world out there!
data.meaning_hint: Picture this woman with direction, knocking down obstruction after obstruction on her path to success.
data.reading_mnemonic: This woman is truly magnificent. Some compare her to a <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball, because of how she knocks down the obstructions in her path like bowling pins.
data.reading_hint: Now imagine that she actually is a bowling ball. Watch her roll down the bowling lane and smash all those stupid pins!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spirit</radical> loses its <radical>skin</radical> as a part of the damages it <kanji>incur</kanji>s after death.
data.meaning_hint: Some spirits get mad when they lose their skin, and this makes them incur their wrath on the living humans that still have skin.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>incur</kanji> the wrath of an angry spirit, you'll feel your skin <reading>hea</reading>t (<ja>ひ</ja>) up.
data.reading_hint: It feels like your skin is cooking! You're turning red. The spirit is trying to incur the same type of skin damage it had done to it by super-heating your skin! Oww owww!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>valley</radical>, spirits are <kanji>abundant</kanji>. Hence the name. Spirit valley has over two billion spirits floating in it.
data.meaning_hint: Just picture those forest spirits from that famous anime film. The woods are full of them. An abundant valley of spirits.
data.reading_mnemonic: In spirit valley, it's not just spirits that are <kanji>abundant</kanji>. There is an abundance of <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>) as well.
data.reading_hint: Imagine an abundant number of spirits and youths hanging out, drinking microbrews and eating avocado toast. Spirit Valley is a weird place.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> causes a <radical>landslide</radical> that causes an <kanji>earthquake</kanji>!!! The earth doesn't just slide, it <kanji>shake</kanji>s and <kanji>quake</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this happening in real time. First it starts to rain really hard, then the ground starts to shift and run, then everything is shaking and quaking so violently it's an earthquake!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> shakes you so violently that you fall over, banging your <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>) on the coffee table. The edge of the coffee table is very sharp, so it cuts into your shin pretty badly.
data.reading_hint: You grab your shin, but the earthquake shakes the coffee table toward you to hit your shin yet again! Ow ow ow stop!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>nine</radical> <radical>flag</radical>s. With these nine flags you take them one by one and put them up your <kanji>butt</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine taking these nine flags... count 'em... and putting them up your butt. With each one that's up there it gets harder and harder to fit the next one in.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that you have nine flags inside your <kanji>butt</kanji>, you have to get them out. But, you don't know how to. So you ask <reading>Siri</reading> (<ja>しり</ja>), "how do I get nine flags out of my butt?"
data.reading_hint: In your head, doing the Siri voice, come up with an answer for your nine flags in the butt predicament.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> stuck in the ground with a little bit of <radical>fur</radical> coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a <kanji>tail</kanji>. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail.
data.meaning_hint: What kind of animal could it be? You start to feel the soft fur with your hand and then the stench of death hits your nostrils. Ew.
data.reading_mnemonic: You try to pull the flag out of the ground and hear a rumbling buzzing sound. At the end of the flagpole you see a huge <reading>bee</reading>hive (<ja>び</ja>)! These bees made their home under the <kanji>tail</kanji>! Maybe that’s why the flag was sticking in it… to warn people. Oops.
data.reading_hint: See the bees swarming out from around the tail and toward your face. Run! Run before there’s nothing left of you but your own tail!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>tree</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> sits with <radical>twenty</radical> little <kanji>contraptions</kanji>. There's little electronic ones, little bopping ones, little walking ones... twenty of them.
data.meaning_hint: Can you even imagine twenty completely unique contraptions? Why don't you try, just for fun.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to know what these <kanji>contraptions</kanji> are for, so you ask. The drunkard says, "These are <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>) contraptions *urp* they're for your uh *blarp* kayak... things."
data.reading_hint: "Kayak contraptions" is pretty vague, but you do have a kayak, so you're tempted anyway. If only you could figure out what each contraption did so you could justify buying some.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>stone</radical> to the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>turkey</radical>. It is <kanji>certain</kanji> that you will damage it.
data.meaning_hint: Try hitting a sponge on a turkey's forehead. Not certain. Now a stone. <kanji>Certain</kanji>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're killing this turkey, and you need to make sure he's dead for <kanji>certain</kanji>. The reason you need to make sure this turkey is dead is because of the <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) in your life. Male chickens get really jealous when turkeys are around.
data.reading_hint: As you smash the stone into the turkey's forehead, yell out "This is for you, my cock! THIS IS FOR YOU!" Your cock lover watches from the shadows.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>woman</radical> sees the <radical>Mona Lisa</radical>, she feels a strong feeling of <kanji>dislike</kanji>. All women dislike the Mona Lisa because of how much attention she gets.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself feeling this strong dislike towards the Mona Lisa. She gets all the attention and you get none. It’s not fair and you’re upset.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dislike</kanji> the Mona Lisa so much you hire <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai to cut her up.
data.reading_hint: Ken walks slowly toward the Mona Lisa, dislike shines in his eyes, but then! He falls for her too. No! Ken, destroy her!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> with the <radical>old</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> is the one who has said many things. That makes them different from everyone, an <kanji>individual</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that leader's old mouth saying things that make the old man stand apart from the others. They are individual from everyone else.
data.reading_mnemonic: As an <kanji>individual</kanji>, one must teach all the <ja><reading>子</reading></ja>s (<ja>こ</ja>) their way. Their individual way.
data.reading_hint: "You must be your own individual. Don't be a sheeple," he says to the <ja>子</ja>s.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> under a <radical>cliff</radical> is going to be under a lot of <kanji>pressure</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being down there with all that dirt. Imagine feeling the pressure closing in around you. It's so hard to breathe... h... help!
data.reading_mnemonic: The dirt being crushed under this <kanji>pressure</kanji> can't help but react by sneezing out, "<reading>Achoo</reading> (<ja>あつ</ja>)!" This sneeze-inducing pressure probably has something to do with where earthquakes come from.
data.reading_hint: Imagine you're the dirt being pressed from every direction, the pressure so strong, and it squeezes an ACHOO right out of you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> sticks a <radical>stick</radical> into the <radical>dirt</radical> to see what might <kanji>exist</kanji> underneath it. Narwhals live in the sea, you see. So they're convinced nothing can exist anywhere else.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a narwhal sticking a stick, and maybe even its horn too, into the dirt on land. It needs to know if life exists outside of the ocean for sure.
data.reading_mnemonic: The narwhal can't find anything but it can't stop thinking about what could <kanji>exist</kanji> outside of its world. It pulls out a <reading>xy</reading>lophone (<ja>ざい</ja>) and starts tapping the keys with its horn. It plays a sad song about the meaning of life and whether existence is worth it.
data.reading_hint: Hear the plinky plink of the xylophone and think about what exists in this world. It's a sad song, you realize.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>net</radical> is upon your <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>evening</radical>. These appear on your head at night whenever you are having a <kanji>dream</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Watch yourself sleeping. Then, a net of flowers appear on your forehead as you start to dream.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dream</kanji> about cows saying "<reading>moo</reading> (<ja>む</ja>), moo, moo!"
data.reading_hint: While still dreaming, you say "moo" out loud too. "Moooo!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> on the <radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Life</radical> and <kanji>give birth</kanji> to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it!
data.meaning_hint: The baby is falling off the cliff! Imagine the sheer terror you feel as the baby plummets to the ground below.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>give birth</kanji>, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>)! He caught your baby!
data.reading_hint: Oh Santa-san. You're always here for me when I need you most. Even when I'm giving birth to your child.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone stabbed the <radical>leader</radical> <radical>mole</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>overthrow</kanji> it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a mole sneaking up behind the leader mole and stabbing him with a knife. This type of overthrowing of leadership feels familiar to you. Maybe this has happened before in the past?
data.reading_mnemonic: Where do leaders get <kanji>overthrow</kanji>n the most? In <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Just think back in Japanese history, back when everyone was at war with one another. People were taking over and getting overthrown and then that guy gets overthrown and then THAT guy gets overthrown. Basically, it used to be hard to stay a leader in <ja>とうきょう</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Picture this like an exaggerated reenactment on the History channel. Leader after leader of <ja>とうきょう</ja> gets overthrown and replaced with the next guy. It never stops. (Until the end of the Edo period, I guess.)

data.meaning_mnemonic: Wash your<radical>self</radical> with a <radical>big</radical> bar of soap if you're <kanji>stinking</kanji> everything up.
data.meaning_hint: Seriously. If you or someone else is stinking to high heaven, embrace a big bar of self care.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>stinking</kanji> up the room because you spent your day rolling in <ja><reading>草</reading></ja> (<ja>くさ</ja>). And based on this particular stench, I'd say an animal left something in that <ja>草</ja> too...
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to use a big bar of soap on yourself to get the stinky <ja>草</ja> off. But it's not working... the <ja>草</ja> stink is SO STRONG!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Hanging off the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> is a <radical>sun</radical> worshipping <radical>child</radical> with a <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries at the sun for cursing him to this cruel fate. Even the thickness of his unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to pull himself back up.
data.meaning_hint: I mean, this unibrow is really, really thick. So thick it doesn’t even look real. But it is. It’s really real and really thick.
data.reading_mnemonic: The child's <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow can't wait any longer and gives up. It hops off the child's face and says, "Hey dude, I'll be <reading>at Sue's</reading> (<ja>あつ</ja>). She'll appreciate my thick, luxuriousness more than a weakling like you.
data.reading_hint: I guess if you want to go see that thick, beautiful unibrow you'll have to go see it at Sue's now. What's that? Oh, don't worry about the child. It uh. It's probably at Sue's too! Maybe... (or dead).

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical>, holding a <radical>brush</radical>, is the <radical>woman</radical> you call your <kanji>wife</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You're standing above your wife, trying to figure out what she's making with her brush on the ground. If you have a real wife in real life, picture her doing this right now.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>wife</kanji> is drawing your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>) on the ground. Oh no... now your wife is making kissy faces at the cyborg drawing.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so your wife may be in love with the cyborg monstrosity you created a while ago. This could become a problem.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> is <radical>righteousness</radical>, at least that's what you believe. You keep talking and saying these things, and you don't listen to anyone else's words. This is your style of <kanji>deliberation</kanji> and <kanji>discussion</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself in a deliberation with some other people. They think what they're saying is right, and it drives you mad. Then you realize that you're doing the same thing.
data.reading_mnemonic: What are you in <kanji>deliberation</kanji> about? Whether or not to send some poor soul to the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>). "I think he should go," you say. "I don't think he should," says another. This <kanji>deliberation</kanji> is going nowhere...
data.reading_hint: Imagine how the deliberation concludes. Then, at the end, someone says "This deliberation is over! We have decided to _________" (in regards to the guillotine).

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>animal</radical> kingdom, a <radical>snake</radical> is the most likely to commit a <kanji>crime</kanji>. Remember the Garden of Eden? The snake was the bad guy. Ever since then, snakes are the animal most known for committing crimes.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a snake as a hardened criminal. See this snake with many prison tattoos and muscles from working out in his jail cell. Hear the snake hissing as it slithers about to commit yet another crime.
data.reading_mnemonic: This snake has evaded the law for too long. It’s time for a true hero to put an end to its <kanji>crime</kanji> spree. Enter <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo. Han Solo is the only man strong and brave enough to put an end to this snake and his crime filled ways.
data.reading_hint: Now see Han Solo doing battle with the snake (cue Star Wars music). The snake hisses and lunges at Han, but Han shoots the snake and it’s incapacitated. Smell the smell of scorched snake flesh in your nose.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>net</radical> around a <radical>criminal</radical> to show their <kanji>guilt</kanji>. Criminals look like anyone else on the street, so you decide to tie them in nets to make sure people know who they're dealing with.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine throwing a net around someone you think, no, you know is guilty of doing something bad to you. It feels pretty nice.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>guilt</kanji> shows on the criminal's face. They smile, shrug, and pull a stolen <reading>xy</reading>lophone (<ja>ざい</ja>) out of their back pocket.
data.reading_hint: Woah! The xylophone is huge, how did they... well whatever, you definitely have proof that they're guilty now and the cops should be here any minute to take your criminal catch.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <radical>building</radical> in the <radical>direction</radical> you want to go it will <kanji>prevent</kanji> you from going any further. Like, come on kid, you think you can just walk right through a building? Don't make me laugh!
data.meaning_hint: There's a building right there. Try to go that direction. Oh, did the building prevent you? Told you so.
data.reading_mnemonic: The building is <kanji>prevent</kanji>ing you from going the right direction, so you pull a <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball out of your bag, aim, and bowl the building over. The building, and all the ones around it, go tumbling down. But now the rubble is preventing you from going further.
data.reading_hint: Your bowling antics are now preventing a bunch of people from going the directions they want to go. Nice job.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hole</radical> radical and the <kanji>hole</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!
data.reading_mnemonic: <reading>Ana</reading> (<ja>あな</ja>) fell into a <kanji>hole</kanji>. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy!
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself laughing at Ana while you point at her, continuing to jeer as Ana struggles to escape the hole. You’d help Ana out of the hole, but you’re too busy laughing at her.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical>, throwing your <radical>hat</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> in front of the <radical>bookshelf</radical>, "I have a <kanji>theory</kanji>!" All this reading and thinking has finally given you a wonderful idea, a theory you think might solve all of your problems!
data.meaning_hint: This theory you've thought of is great, it's going to change everything!
data.reading_mnemonic: "What is your theory, <reading>Ron</reading> (<ja>ろん</ja>)?" asks Hermione. You're Ron Weasley, and you just came up with a theory that you think will help you stop Voldemort.
data.reading_hint: "Ron? Ron, what's your theory? What's your theory, Ron?" Hermione asks over and over. But you freeze. You don't remember who you are. "Hermione, I have a theory that I was just a person learning Japanese, and not a magical boy at all." "Shut up Ron, that's a stupid theory," she replies.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Tying a <radical>thread</radical> to a <radical>tombstone</radical> each year will help you <kanji>manage</kanji> the <kanji>passage of time</kanji>. That way you’ll know how many years it has been, since you’ll have one thread for each year to count.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself coming back to the same tombstone each passing year and tying a new thread to it. You're trying to manage these feelings by keeping track of how much time passes.
data.reading_mnemonic: Dealing with the <kanji>passage of time</kanji> can be tough, so after you tie the thread to the tombstone, each year you eat a piece of <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>). You already eat cake to mark the passage of time on your birthday, so why not here as well?
data.reading_hint: Maybe this is your future tombstone, and eating cake each year is a preemptive celebration of your death day! Ooh, what a spooky theory.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Is there a <radical>reason</radical> you're in the <radical>bamboo</radical> grove? Why yes there is. It's so you can get yourself some bamboo and make a <kanji>flute</kanji> out of it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself cutting down some bamboo, thinking "this is the reason I'm here, I need a flute, asap!" There is no other reason to be here besides this.
data.reading_mnemonic: You cut down the bamboo and whittle a <kanji>flute</kanji>. You start playing a song. You know the reason why. An alien spacecraft comes flying down and drops a box full of alien <reading>tech</reading> (<ja>てき</ja>) in front of you.
data.reading_hint: You've done what you came to do. You summoned an alien craft with your bamboo flute, gaining some alien tech in the process. Open up the box to see what tech awaits you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>history</radical> radical and the <kanji>history</kanji> kanji are the same.
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>History</kanji> was full of famous <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). Sure there are people and stuff, but historical sheep are where it's at. There's the famous sheep samurai, the death sheep who works for the yakuza, just tons!
data.reading_hint: Look at a history book, behind each of those humans was a sheep, changing the world as we know it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>sheep</radical> are <kanji>detailed</kanji> creatures. I mean, I never thought sheep were very detailed, but that’s what they say.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine getting really close to a sheep and seeing all the tiny detailed curls in their wool. There are hidden patterns you'd never noticed before now!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason these sheep are so <kanji>detailed</kanji> is that they are trying to impress the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). If they're fancy enough, perhaps the Shougun won’t kill them for their meat and make their wool into clothing.
data.reading_hint: Picture the Shougun, leaning in close to inspect the detailed patterns all over the sheep. His nose is so close, he can probably smell all the little detailed nuances of the sheep's musk too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under his <radical>roof</radical>, the <radical>king</radical> stares into a <radical>drop</radical> of water containing his greatest <kanji>treasure</kanji>. Just kidding, the king has way more treasure than that. The drop of water is just reflecting what's around him: mounds and mounds of treasure, stacked all the way up to the roof.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the treasure reflected in the drop of water. It's marvelous!
data.reading_mnemonic: All of this <kanji>treasure</kanji> is kept in the king's <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>). He can't let other people see how much treasure he has, or they'll get mad, or worse(!) ask him to share some with his people. Yuck. The treasure stays at home.
data.reading_hint: Picture his home from the outside. It looks like a normal, small castle. But then you walk in and it's a treasure trove of... well, treasure!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> kills a <radical>pig</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> in this new <kanji>drama</kanji> about the animal kingdom! The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger, but now they're bitter enemies and the tiger just stabbed the pig right in the chest with a knife.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this scene from the drama as dramatically as you can. The pig stares into the tiger's eyes, "Tiger, you wouldn't–uh!" The pig's eyes slowly lower to see the knife sticking into its gut, the tiger's hand still holding it. "This is what you get, you pig," the tiger spits back, twisting.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>drama</kanji> is being put on by <reading>Gecki</reading> (<ja>げき</ja>), your childhood pet gecko. Gecki is playing all the parts, because as true drama fans know, one-gecko-shows are the highest form of art.
data.reading_hint: Picture Gecki acting out the part of the tiger and the pig in this drama. It's so intense, you're moved to tears. Bravo Gecki, bravo!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>business</radical>? Ha! That's <kanji>me</kanji>! That's <kanji>I</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: This version of <kanji>I</kanji> is more boyish. It's a sort of young man/boy way of saying "I," though you'll hear women use it too sometimes (it's a teensy bit tomboyish though).
data.reading_mnemonic: You use the word <kanji>I</kanji> a lot. You say it so much, you just start referring to yourself with the french <reading>beaucoup</reading> (<ja>ぼく</ja>) for a lot. Because you love yourself a lot.
data.reading_hint: I am beaucoup I am. (Is that a pun? Did I do it right?) I dunno. Just say <ja>ぼく</ja> a lot and try to connect all of your approximate knowledges of languages together. Merci <ja>ぼく</ja> from <ja>ぼく</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>height</radical> radical and the <kanji>height</kanji> kanji are the same!

That said, there's a secondary meaning to this kanji of <kanji>ten feet</kanji>. So, when you think of height, think of that height as being ten feet tall.
data.meaning_hint: If you paid attention in radicals school, you'll be able to learn this kanji meaning easily.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you think of <kanji>height</kanji> think of our huge farmhand friend, <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>). He's a big guy, and he has a lot of height to him. In fact, he's <kanji>ten feet</kanji> tall.
data.reading_hint: Jourm really is a big guy. Look up at him, and try to measure him, but ten feet is too high for you to reach.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Into your <radical>mouth</radical> the <radical>leader</radical> shot an <radical>arrow</radical> with an attached <radical>hook</radical> so that they'd be able to see into your <kanji>throat</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the arrow with its hook shooting down into your mouth and hooking into your throat. Ouch! Now the leader is peering down in there, but you don't know why.
data.reading_mnemonic: From your <kanji>throat</kanji> you hear a voice. Not yours, but one you recognize. It's <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>! What's that rascal doing down in your throat?
data.reading_hint: The leader starts to tug <ja>こういち</ja> out of your throat, but he resists. "No, I like it down here, it's dark and damp." The leader gets angry and pulls harder, which hurts! This is your throat, after all, don't you get a say?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>mouth</radical> is a <radical>stamp</radical> that you <kanji>strike</kanji> and <kanji>beat</kanji> to create a beat! The stamp looks like a little drum, but you're really just hitting your mouth for fun (the stamp was an excuse to make it seem normal).
data.meaning_hint: Put a stamp on your mouth and look in your bathroom mirror. Now strike that stamp and make a fresh new beat the young kids can dance to!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>strike</kanji> and <kanji>beat</kanji> your own mouth, <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja> comes dancing into your bathroom. "Hey now, this looks fun, can I beat your mouth up a bit too?" he asks.
data.reading_hint: <ja>こういち</ja> doesn't wait for you to remove the stamp to answer, and instead starts striking your mouth to make his own beats. Rude! He should have asked for permission before beating on you, even if you would have said yes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What do you <radical>eat</radical> like a <radical>machine</radical>? <kanji>Candy</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Picture your mouth opening and closing really fast and hard as candy on a conveyor belt goes sliding in. Munch, munch, munch, you're a candy machine!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>candy</kanji> in particular is just drops of hardened, clear sugar that looks like <reading><ja>雨</ja></reading> (<ja>あめ</ja>) drops.
data.reading_hint: Picture this kanji rain as it goes into your chomping machine mouth. It tastes like sweet, sugary <ja>雨</ja>. Yum!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>axe</radical> radical and the <kanji>axe</kanji> kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji>, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine you've gone back in time a good hundred years, and you're trying to count loaves of bread after each swing of your axe. Axes and bread loaves will become intertwined in your brain.
data.reading_mnemonic: You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an <kanji>axe</kanji> to be a <kanji>bread loaf counter</kanji> for the <reading>Kin</reading>g (<ja>きん</ja>) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being stuck using an axe on bread while the King of England glares down at you, munching and spilling crumbs everywhere.
